commit_message:
Delete python bytecode before every test run

Because python creates pyc|pyo files and __pycache__
directories during tox runs, certain changes in the tree,
like deletes of files, or switching branches, can create
spurious errors.

The target bytecodes for deletion are in normal directories,
but not in dot started directory.

Change-Id: Iee36c67d2e5e4d9e78b1b1b493030761e0f46e3c
Closes-Bug: #1368661
(cherry picked from commit 83d61566cee8b8e786b46103cf3e72fbe8077c1a)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-neutronclient refs/changes/68/296568/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Delete bytecodes from normal directories before running tests. # Note that bytecodes in dot directories will not be deleted # to keep bytecodes of python modules installed into virtualenvs. commands = sh -c "find . -type d -name '.?*' -prune -o \ \( -type d -name '__pycache__' -o -type f -name '*.py[co]' \) \ -print0 | xargs -0 rm -rf" python setup.py testr --testr-args='{posargs}' whitelist_externals = sh

commit_message:
Improve networking-ovn/testing.rst

Make it a little friendlier to copy and paste command used
for adding internal OVS port.

Make it a little more explicit the mac address to be used
for the added interface.

Patch set 2: line wrap the added text

Change-Id: I8404b1b57c02d1c3271a3d456efed386c8fba377
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/networking-ovn refs/changes/31/311231/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: set Interface lport1 external_ids:iface-id=IFACE_ID \ type=internal Replace ``IFACE_ID`` with the UUID of the neutron port. Based on the example output above, that would be ``92b4f192-7247-4ba0-88ad-40ce1d950e52``. # ip link set dev lport1 address MAC_ADDRESS Replace ``MAC_ADDRESS`` with the mac address of the neutron port. Based on the example output above, that would be ``fa:16:3e:23:6a:ab``.
deleted_lines: > set Interface lport1 external_ids:iface-id=IFACE_ID \ > type=internal Replace ``IFACE_ID`` with the UUID of the neutron port. # ip link set dev lport1 address fa:16:3e:23:6a:ab

Issue deprecation message for the barbican CLI

The barbican CLI has been deprecated and users should use the openstack
unified CLI instead.

Change-Id: Ie78b2c913b1520f1df312ab7a11e0132f0c36d26

commit_message:
Volume: remove a useless `_delete_volume_type` alias

We shouldn"t allow people to alias client methods like this. It gives
a bad opinion on Tempest code base: lack of consistency, code harder
to read (because you constently have to switch between test code and
methods definition).

Change-Id: Ic52159ad72246cc5d8fc5ef3bb7877b8b8d8821b

great !

commit_message:
Enable sorting and pagination in -api gate

There is a plan to get those enabled by default in next cycles. For
that, we should first ensure that test coverage for the feature is
decent. Sadly, there are currently no API tests for those features

all. So the first step is to enable those optional features in -api

After that, we can start working on test coverage in tre tree. Once

get to the point when we are sure coverage is good enough, we can
proceed with the plan to enable it by default for all operators.

Related-Bug: #1566514
Change-Id: I94177604b4ac3f8b42521e2231f10363fe8e4483
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/34/301634/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: cfg.BoolOpt('allow_pagination', default=True, cfg.BoolOpt('allow_sorting', default=True,

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-03-14 13:48:45.000000000', 'files': ['global-requirements.txt'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/requirements/commit/e32decef5b510eeb1e8497a8eeedda7bbf7f7d6f', 'message': 'Require iso8601>=0.1.11

python-openstacksdk uses "iso8601.UTC" which does not work in
iso8601 version 0.1.9. Running python-openstacksdk tests with 0.1.9
on python 2.7 fails with:

AttributeError: 'module' object has no attribute 'UTC'

Change-Id: I0282763a6c563277d9b176920e0dec2e07512100
'}]
commit_message:
Require iso8601>=0.1.11

python-openstacksdk uses "iso8601.UTC" which does not work in
iso8601 version 0.1.9. Running python-openstacksdk tests with 0.1.9
on python 2.7 fails with:

AttributeError: 'module' object has no attribute 'UTC'

Change-Id: I0282763a6c563277d9b176920e0dec2e07512100
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/requirements refs/changes/96/292396/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

Replace tempest-lib with tempest.lib

tempest-lib is deprecated, so replace it with tempest.lib.

commit_message:
Maintenance nodes automatic recovery for sync power failed nodes

Co-Authored-By: Xiaobin, Qu <jxiaobin@ebaysf.com>

Change-Id: I4790d47e1fa413038772b74b128cd10590fae9a3
Related-bug: #1554686
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic-specs refs/changes/90/292190/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ==================================== Maintenance nodes automatic recovery ==================================== https://bugs.launchpad.net/ironic/+bug/1554686 This blueprint proposes adding a way to automatic recovery the nodes from maintenance status. Problem description =================== Ironic nodes will be put under maintenance for some reason, for example, temporary BMC offline or unreachable. Once nodes are put under maintenance, human has to take them out of the state manually, which is unacceptable for large deployment. This way "maintenance" nodes can get out of "maintenance" without human interference, so that automatic recovery function is required to avoid manually human maintenance actions. Proposed change =============== Proposal is, when run "_sync_power_states", do not exclude "maintenance" nodes, scan them at longer interval, and if "do_sync_power_state" succeeds, flip the "maintenance" status. In order to exactly get nodes which maintenance status is due to sync power state error, we will introduce new field into node.maintenance_reason, the data model as below: maintenance_reason.code: To indicate why this nodes is marked to maintenance status, such as sync power error, or clean error etc. maintenance_reason.msg: The details information of maintenance reason, keep as original concept and design, just move maintenance_reason to maintenance_reason.msg. Examples: maintenance_reason={"code":"SYNC_POWER_ERROR","During sync_power_state, max retries exceeded for node ..."} maintenance_reason={"code":"BY_CLI","Remove this server from baremetal pool."} Alternatives ------------ Data model impact ----------------- None. State Machine Impact -------------------- None. REST API impact --------------- None Client (CLI) impact ------------------- None RPC API impact -------------- None. Driver API impact ----------------- None. Nova driver impact ------------------ None. Security impact --------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None. Scalability impact ------------------ None. Performance Impact ------------------ None. Other deployer impact --------------------- None. Developer impact ---------------- None. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: whaom Work Items ---------- * Define maintenance reason codes * Add new Ironic option - automatic_recovery_maintenance_codes, define the codes, which automatic recovery is enabled or not. * Modify _sync_power_states filter, to include nodes in maintenance status * Add new logic into _sync_power_states call, to change maintenance to false, which node's maintenance_reason.code=SYNC_POWER_ERROR and the power control is back. Dependencies ============ None. Testing ======= Will add unit test code to cover the conductor manager code changes. Upgrades and Backwards Compatibility ==================================== None. Documentation Impact ==================== Update API document adding a new API References ========== None.

commit_message:
Preserve Swift paths that start with '/'

Objects uploaded to Swift can start with '/', so we should not strip it
out of the Swift path.  We can temporarily strip it out of the log_name
when calculating the safe path (which is the path on disk we're looking
for).

Change-Id: I25031f2c1be91c9f82b17a15f3ee4bdf07303cb8

subject: gate: bump resource quotas x10 times
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-04-05 13:57:14.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/eb3435f6e4ec19cd8b02b3785a5ed8bad3360d6b', 'message': 'gate: bump resource quotas x10 times

Default values are too low in case new test cases want to create more of
their own resources. Sadly, tempest took a cleanup path where test cases
do not clean after them, instead postponing it to test suite completion.
It would be more in line with other projects relying on tempest
framework just to bump quotas and wait for the next time we need to bump
them.

Change-Id: I01ffc4ad485dff299dab4e3f49d2dcc0e950fc44

commit_message:
gate: bump resource quotas x10 times

Default values are too low in case new test cases want to create more of
their own resources. Sadly, tempest took a cleanup path where test cases
do not clean after themselves, instead postponing it to test suite
completion.  It would be more in line with other projects relying on
tempest framework just to bump quotas and wait for the next time we need
to bump them.

Change-Id: I01ffc4ad485dff299dab4e3f49d2dcc0e950fc44

commit_message:
Move shade job from experimental to non-voting

To continue with shade+magnum integration, start moving
one of the jobs from experimental to check, to test
the integration on every change. This is a previous step
to update the real shade job, to add magnum plugin.

Change-Id: I23ca2a6e58d4b14d16f8754c926f334a3fb7a160

git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-ec2api refs/changes/46/310546/12 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: require 'spec_helper' describe 'ec2api::db::sync' do shared_examples_for 'ec2api-dbsync' do it 'runs ec2api-db-sync' do is_expected.to contain_exec('ec2api-db-sync').with( :command => 'ec2api-manage db_sync', :path => '/usr/bin', :user => 'ec2api', :refreshonly => 'true' ) end describe "overriding extra_params" do let :params do { :extra_params => '--config-file /etc/ec2api/ec2api.conf', } end it { is_expected.to contain_exec('ec2api-db-sync').with( :command => 'ec2api-manage db_sync --config-file /etc/ec2api/ec2api.conf', :path => '/usr/bin', :user => 'ec2api', :refreshonly => 'true' ) } end end context 'on a RedHat osfamily' do let :facts do @default_facts.merge({ :osfamily => 'RedHat', :operatingsystemrelease => '7.0', :concat_basedir => '/var/lib/puppet/concat' }) end it_configures 'ec2api-dbsync' end context 'on a Debian osfamily' do let :facts do @default_facts.merge({ :operatingsystemrelease => '7.8', :operatingsystem => 'Debian', :osfamily => 'Debian', :concat_basedir => '/var/lib/puppet/concat' }) end it_configures 'ec2api-dbsync' end end

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-04-29 22:42:52.000000000', 'files': ['zuul/layout.yaml', 'jenkins/jobs/devstack-gate.yaml'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/project-config/commit/bfaab3ba43575a6bfb3198115d55b55966e508f3', 'message': 'Remove experimental nova-v20-api-legacy job

There are two implementation code for similar API in Nova repository.
One is newer: v2.1 API, another is legacy: v2 API. v2.1 API has been
used as the default API since Liberty and legacy v2 API has been marked
as deprecated.
We have used and tested v2.1 API so well and now is nice time to remove
legacy API code based on the consensus of the design summit of Austin.

This patch removes experimental job for legacy API code.

Partially implements blueprint remove-legacy-v2-api-code

Change-Id: Iac81b7d569b76b99e9d86eaa5001ae7f9b78cdfe
'}]
commit_message:
Remove experimental nova-v20-api-legacy job

There are two implementation code for similar API in Nova repository.
One is newer: v2.1 API, another is legacy: v2 API. v2.1 API has been
used as the default API since Liberty and legacy v2 API has been marked
as deprecated.
We have used and tested v2.1 API so well and now is nice time to remove
legacy API code based on the consensus of the design summit of Austin.

This patch removes experimental job for legacy API code.

Partially implements blueprint remove-legacy-v2-api-code

Change-Id: Iac81b7d569b76b99e9d86eaa5001ae7f9b78cdfe
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/project-config refs/changes/60/311360/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
deleted_lines: - job-template: name: '{pipeline}-tempest-dsvm-nova-v20-api-legacy{job-suffix}' node: '{node}' wrappers: - build-timeout: timeout: 180 - timestamps builders: - print-template-name: template-name: "{template-name}" - link-logs - net-info - devstack-checkout - shell: | #!/bin/bash -xe export PYTHONUNBUFFERED=true export DEVSTACK_GATE_TEMPEST=1 # 2 line vars are so much fun export DEVSTACK_LOCAL_CONFIG="TEMPEST_COMPUTE_TYPE=compute_legacy" export DEVSTACK_LOCAL_CONFIG+=$'\n'"NOVA_V2_LEGACY=True" # only run compute API tests export DEVSTACK_GATE_TEMPEST_REGEX="api.*compute" export BRANCH_OVERRIDE={branch-override} if [ "$BRANCH_OVERRIDE" != "default" ] ; then export OVERRIDE_ZUUL_BRANCH=$BRANCH_OVERRIDE fi cp devstack-gate/devstack-vm-gate-wrap.sh ./safe-devstack-vm-gate-wrap.sh ./safe-devstack-vm-gate-wrap.sh publishers: - devstack-logs - console-log - '{pipeline}-tempest-dsvm-nova-v20-api-legacy{job-suffix}'

In order to consider switching to native interfaces to

Change-Id: I252902d0a0debe6fae4d023cd118ef20f15b47d9
'}]
commit_message:
Enhance Neutron OVS native jobs

In order to consider switching to native interfaces to
OVS (i.e. using Ryu/OVS Python IDL libraries rather than
shelling out with rootwrap), we need to start watching
these jobs to see how they perform. Before doing that,
we need both native interfaces to be enabled.

Change-Id: I252902d0a0debe6fae4d023cd118ef20f15b47d9

The Neutron with VLAN segmentation is now declared compatible
with both QEMU and vCenter

commit_message:
Revert "remove the use of import_object_ns"

This reverts commit 8eb03de1eb83a6cd2d4d41804e1b8253f94e5400.

The change being reverted broke out of tree virt drivers
without any deprecation cycle, which we at least did with the
manager plugins and other plug-points in Mitaka.

We should at least provide a deprecation cycle so the out of
tree virt drivers can have time to adjust to this.

Change-Id: If70842863b1991485c0464f01b3568bf31166161

commit_message:
libvirt: remove version checks for hyperv PV features

The hyperv paravirt features requires libvirt 1.1.0 and QEMU
1.1.0 which are both older than our min required versions.
Thus we can remove the versions checks for the hyperv
paravirt features.

Change-Id: Iff6a4557515294fe6856e53a368870c5fff79c96

commit_message:
libvirt: remove version checks for block job handling

The volume snapshot code requires libvirt 1.1.1 in order
to get a fix for block job handling, which is older than
our min required libvirt version. Thus we can remove the
version checks for this feature.

Change-Id: I59647b995b9243a290d2290142f025a686f84832

commit_message:
Remove unneeded default arg

In the CreateNetwork libnetwork endpoint impl, the
function utils.make_net_name passes unneeded default
argument tags=app.tag, but since make_net_name is not
dependent on whether tag support is enabled or not, we
don't need it. This patch simply removes that default
arg.

Change-Id: Ieb557b3dc2ce0b84678dadf36b7b81661d64db07

#!/bin/bash # # Setup a Designate devstack based on Ubuntu Trusty using libvirt # and run a quick CLI test and the functional tests # # To be run from <Designate repo>/contrib/vagrant # set -eu test -f Vagrantfile if vagrant global-status | grep ' ubuntu ' | grep -q 'contrib/vagrant'; then echo "A devstack VM seems to be already running, see vagrant global-status" exit 1 fi if vagrant plugin list | grep -q ^vagrant-mutate; then echo "Skip installing vagrant-mutate" else echo "Install vagrant-mutate" vagrant plugin install vagrant-mutate fi if vagrant box list | grep -q ^ubuntu/trusty64; then echo "Skip downloading Vagrant box" else echo "Download and convert box" vagrant box add --provider virtualbox ubuntu/trusty64 vagrant mutate ubuntu/trusty64 libvirt fi echo "Check running pool" virsh pool-info default | grep ^State | grep -q running # Workaround for https://github.com/fog/fog-libvirt/issues/16 # vagrant plugin install fog-libvirt --plugin-version 0.0.3 --verbose vagrant up ubuntu vmrun() { vagrant ssh ubuntu -c "$@" } vmrun "sudo apt-get update" vmrun "sudo apt-get install httpie -y" vmrun "echo export LC_ALL=en_US.UTF-8 >> .bashrc" vmrun "echo export LC_CTYPE=en_US.UTF-8 >> .bashrc" vmrun "sudo dpkg-reconfigure locales" vmrun "cd devstack && ./stack.sh" echo -e "
stack.sh run completed. Showing server-list:
" vmrun "cd devstack && source openrc admin demo && designate server-list" echo -e "
Running functional tests
" vmrun "cd /opt/stack/designate && tox -e functional -v" echo "Done. Run vagrant ssh ubuntu to log in"

commit_message:
Add filter function on resource type table

Resource Types panel in Orchestration panel group has a resources
type table. This table does not have a filter function even though
the number of colums is over 90.
This patch add a filter function to this table.

Change-Id: I66e950b1acc3d9ea70fff5545cc0cc7fce6fa500
Closes-bug: #1569681

commit_message:
Fix revert migration if flavor deleted

After an instance is created, the flavor could be deleted.  But
operations still need to be able to occur against the VM when that
occurs.  A new test in Tempest showed that we had been using the
incorrect (and potentially deleted) flavor when a resize/migration was
reverting.

This change updates the code to use the flavor that is stored on the
instance itself.

Change-Id: I16254d8eb74a724e3e0a538f47259e9627c4233a
Closes-Bug: 1570748

commit_message:
libvirt: remove version checks for live snapshot feature

The live snapshot feature requires libvirt 1.0.0 and QEMU 1.3.0
which are both older than our minimum required versions. Thus we
can remove the version checks for this feature.

Change-Id: I22d7545ec9d073498b070de274f5a58e32c80df5

commit_message:
Support local_id configuration

In some case, we want to specify the local id instead of use the
external ip. For example, the router is behind NAT, and we don't
want to expose this IP to peer. This patch will make local_id
configurable. Most often, local id would be domain name, email
address etc. But if local id is not configured then external ip
will still be used as the leftid.

Note: this change is DocImpact & APIImpact

Change-Id: I2433d72ba22ce410cbfafb7b8bfb16f51eefdfc1
Closes-Bug: #1513353

commit_message:
Pre_delete job for MongoDB nodes

MongoDB nodes should be deleted from MongoDB cluster
first, then they can be removed from Fuel cluster.

Change-Id: I549497d7bea615bc482ad331e86b9fdf64b92eda
Closes-bug: #1513736

commit_message:
Fixed output of cluster-create in CLI

When running cluster-create, the CLI prints the instances created as
part of the output.  This causes the results to scroll off the screen
and makes it very difficult to see what happened.

The output of cluster-create has been consolidated with that of
cluster-show, in much the same way as is done with create and show
for single instances.

Change-Id: Id4eecc236b6c1ec43b47714ac5eabd8323a5b996
Closes-Bug: #1563504

deleted_lines: info = cluster._info.copy() info['datastore'] = cluster.datastore['type'] info['datastore_version'] = cluster.datastore['version'] info['task_name'] = cluster.task['name'] info['task_description'] = cluster.task['description'] del info['task'] if hasattr(cluster, 'ip'): info['ip'] = ', '.join(cluster.ip) del info['instances'] cluster._info = info _print_object(cluster) cluster._info['task_name'] = cluster.task['name'] cluster._info['task_description'] = cluster.task['description'] del cluster._info['task'] cluster._info['datastore'] = cluster.datastore['type'] cluster._info['datastore_version'] = cluster.datastore['version'] del cluster._info['instances'] _print_object(cluster)

commit_message:
libvirt: increase min required libvirt to 1.2.1

As advertized during Mitaka, increase the min required
libvirt version to 1.2.1.

At this time there is no new "next" version planned.
The need to advertize a version increase for Ocata
will be decided later.

Change-Id: Ib73cfbd9fc01114ac513730d182ed127710a9e5d

The disk backing file discard support requires libvirt 1.0.6
which is older than our min required libvirt versiron. Thus we

commit_message:
libvirt: remove version checks for libvirt disk discard feature

The disk backing file discard support requires libvirt 1.0.6
which is older than our min required libvirt versiron. Thus we
can remove the libvirt version checks for this feature.

Change-Id: I034469b86a7cd839b6099b55e484da8060ce02a2

argparse parser object does not have .abort(), so the script fails with

Instead of calling to a non-existent method, we now raise SystemExit
showing the corresponding error message extracted from the caught
exception, as in:

$ new-release kilo networking-ofagent bugfix
creating temporary files in /tmp/releases-UC3QMk

Change-Id: I71fc86251b7a48504e4ffcf1f0d715feb96141ab
"}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2016-04-21 18:50:17.000000000', 'files': ['openstack_releases/cmds/new_release.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/releases/commit/82e13a6c10dc861e6c7dc3cf40b0023fe0d4ae34', 'message': "new_release: fixed error handling when opening deliverable file

argparse parser object does not have .abort(), so the script fails with
AttributeError stacktrace if e.g. the file does not exist.

The intention of the original author was to call .error() so that's what
we now use here.

Change-Id: I71fc86251b7a48504e4ffcf1f0d715feb96141ab
"}]
commit_message:
new_release: fixed error handling when opening deliverable file

argparse parser object does not have .abort(), so the script fails with
AttributeError stacktrace if e.g. the file does not exist.

The intention of the original author was to call .error() so that's what
we now use here.

Change-Id: I71fc86251b7a48504e4ffcf1f0d715feb96141ab

commit_message:
libvirt: add explicit check for min required QEMU version

Previously Nova only checked the minimum required libvirt
version. It should also be checking for a minimum required
QEMU version.

This picks QEMU version 1.5.3, since that is the oldest
QEMU version that exists in the distros that include
the minimum libvirt version 1.2.1.

No decision is made about a "next" QEMU version at this
time.

Change-Id: Ie9413338a2422cc876f48c5c477eb3cd0ffb13ec

commit_message:
Add req to pycrypto to fix import errors

We're not sure...

But we think paramiko's recent 2.0.0 release somehow breaks a
requirement chain where *somebody* needs pycrypto and is no longer
getting it.  Adding the requirement for pycrypto (synced with the
corresponding global requirement) resolves the tox errors seen in the
bug report.

And the gate wasn't failing because... the pycrypto req was being picked
up some other way.

Change-Id: I1286b7df7df6608a2fdb929eb55f2d6fbfd031ea
Closes-Bug: 1576822

commit_message:
Add spec-cleaner to list of global-requirements

spec-cleaner is a program to enforce a specfic style for
RPM .spec files. It's similar to pep8 for python code, but
spec-cleaner doesn't have a specification. The library is
only used for testing and is not needed while running any
OpenStack component.

The rpm-packaging project.

Yes. It's available on https://github.com/openSUSE/spec-cleaner and
a couple of different people are working on it. The module as also
a big unittest suite.

Available and also tested with unittests.

Yes. It's BSD licensed.

Change-Id: I41ebffcb6646c3c44e469f6393a1aef86bcd927e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/requirements refs/changes/73/311473/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

subject: treat alarm id as name if it is not uuid like
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-04-24 13:23:29.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/python-aodhclient/commit/701a1a59cd7f631a08b109a386ae8267a89f9a04', 'message': 'treat alarm id as name if it is not uuid like

We can specify alarm name to do alarm {show, update, delete}, but
need to explicitly use --alarm-name, which seems not so convenient.

This patch adds a check for postional argument, if it is uuid like,
we treat it as alarm id, if not, we treat it as name.

If name is a uuid like string, this will not work, and return a
404 code, in case of such scenario, adds a detailed help message
for this ambiguous field.

Change-Id: I936fbe66d2711db49c48d6a73638103fe8e5603e
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2016-04-25 15:47:05.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/python-aodhclient/commit/e214a469c74cf8f4a8a9ca6d3d30bef4c3bd0606', 'message': 'treat alarm id as name if it is not uuid like

We can specify alarm name to do alarm {show, update, delete}, but
need to explicitly use --alarm-name, which seems not so convenient.

This patch adds a check for postional argument, if it is uuid like,
we treat it as alarm id, if not, we treat it as name.

If name is a uuid like string, this will not work, and return a
404 code, in case of such scenario, adds a detailed help message
for this ambiguous field.

Change-Id: I936fbe66d2711db49c48d6a73638103fe8e5603e
'}, {'number': 3, 'created': '2016-04-26 07:36:48.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/python-aodhclient/commit/e2c3fe4bf56d15722a7f40178a23abb8232a33c3', 'message': 'treat alarm id as name if it is not uuid like

We can specify alarm name to do alarm {show, update, delete}, but
need to explicitly use --alarm-name, which seems not so convenient.

This patch adds a check for postional argument, if it is UUID like,
we treat it as alarm id, if not, we treat it as name.

However, there is a rare case that a name can be UUID like as well,
command will fail with 404 and people will treat it as a bug. We
can do an extra request for 404 error to try to use the value as
name, but it will sacrifice normal 404 case for unnecessary time
cost.

So an environment variable named AODH_AMBIGUOUS_ID will be checked,
only if its value is literally true, then we will allow
put name as positional argument, and if the name is UUID like,
no 404 raised for the first request, we will do an extra request
to check if the UUID liked name exist.

Change-Id: I936fbe66d2711db49c48d6a73638103fe8e5603e

need to explicitly use --alarm-name, which seems not so convenient.

This patch adds a check for postional argument, if it is UUID like,
we treat it as alarm id, if not, we treat it as name.

However, there is a rare case that a name can be UUID like as well,
command will fail with 404 and people will treat it as a bug. We
can do an extra request for 404 error to try to use the value as
name, but it will sacrifice normal 404 case for unnecessary time
cost.

So an environment variable named AODH_AMBIGUOUS_ID will be checked,
only if its value is literally true, then we will allow
put name as positional argument, and if the name is UUID like,
no 404 raised for the first request, we will do an extra request
to check if the UUID liked name exist.

Change-Id: I936fbe66d2711db49c48d6a73638103fe8e5603e

We can specify alarm name to do alarm {show, update, delete}, but
need to explicitly use --alarm-name, which seems not so convenient.

This patch adds a check for postional argument, if it is UUID like,
we treat it as alarm id, if not, we treat it as name.

However, there is a rare case that a name can be UUID like as well,
command will fail with 404 and people will treat it as a bug. We

commit_message:
treat alarm id as name if it is not uuid like

We can specify alarm name to do alarm {show, update, delete}, but
need to explicitly use --alarm-name, which seems not so convenient.

This patch adds a check for postional argument, if it is UUID like,
we treat it as alarm id, if not, we treat it as name.

However, there is a rare case that a name can be UUID like as well,
command will fail with 404 and people will treat it as a bug. We
can do an extra request for 404 error to try to use the value as
name, but it will sacrifice normal 404 case for unnecessary time
cost.

So an environment variable named AODH_AMBIGUOUS_ID will be checked,
only if its value is literally true, then we will allow
put name as positional argument, and if the name is UUID like,
no 404 raised for the first request, we will do an extra request
to check if the UUID liked name exist.

Change-Id: I936fbe66d2711db49c48d6a73638103fe8e5603e

commit_message:
Change graph date format on tooltip

This commit changes graph date formant on tooltip. We should show not
only date but also time because if we set the period to "a day", it's
hard to understand when it happened.

Change-Id: Iaf9fec29e9e09a2f1b4a16f9080693c25a1cb7ae
Closes-Bug: #1576790

commit_message:
Blacklist cryptography 1.3.0

cryptography 1.3.0 started using it's deprecated module utility for a
public API used by Glance. This utility did not tolerate patching very
well and when a patch context manager would exit, it would fail to
delete the patched attribute. This has been fixed since 1.3.0 was
released but the fix has not yet been released. Until then, let's avoid
1.3.0

Change-Id: Ic442bc1cf03d103d85ad1e2acb42c10e882647be
Related-bug: 1560060
(cherry picked from commit 6f01bcfd8438d03f4d87bc6d3bec5dce3304e9a8)

commit_message:
Test: fix some wrong use of Mock method

There is no method called_once_with() in Mock object.
And called_once_with() does nothing because it's a mock object.

1. In case `test_execute_backup`, there is no state `NEW` any more,
so remove this assertion.
Use assert_has_calls() intead of called_once_with().

2. In case `test_execute_bad_process_backup`, just need to verify that
BackupError will be raised when the runner check_process falsely.
So remove all the wrong assertions called_once_with().

3. In case `test_execute_lossy_backup`, add `BUILDING` state check, and
use assert_has_calls() instead of called_once_with().

4. In case `test_restore_unknown`, use assert_called_once_with() instead
of called_once_with().

Change-Id: Ic23e229de36b5787c66a54f971e81e82d0e718fc
Closes-Bug: #1544522

subject: Blacklist broken Babel releases
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-04-21 03:17:03.000000000', 'files': ['global-requirements.txt'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/requirements/commit/b7c9502f924acc4f8e13b1e561520f14a90535a3', 'message': 'Blacklist broken Babel releases

Babel 2.3.2 failed to parse horizon.
Babel 2.3.3 fixes this but breaks all python projects, the log-level log
files contain far too much content ;(

From https://github.com/python-babel/babel/issues/388:
* versions 2.3.0..2.3.2 break multiple -k/--keywords arguments for
  pybabel extract
* version 2.3.3 breaks the single -k/--keywords argument accepted by
  distutils extract_messages

Blacklist all these versions, and downgrade constraints.

Change-Id: Ia61e96963c0c81814d89c247c82fd75c6ab86a81
(cherry picked from commit 5a9ac571092d515d0de9ee9eee88b1b7878f9cc0)
'}]
commit_message:
Blacklist broken Babel releases

Babel 2.3.2 failed to parse horizon.
Babel 2.3.3 fixes this but breaks all python projects, the log-level log
files contain far too much content ;(

From https://github.com/python-babel/babel/issues/388:
* versions 2.3.0..2.3.2 break multiple -k/--keywords arguments for
  pybabel extract
* version 2.3.3 breaks the single -k/--keywords argument accepted by
  distutils extract_messages

Blacklist all these versions, and downgrade constraints.

Change-Id: Ia61e96963c0c81814d89c247c82fd75c6ab86a81
(cherry picked from commit 5a9ac571092d515d0de9ee9eee88b1b7878f9cc0)

commit_message:
Blacklist broken Babel releases

Babel 2.3.2 failed to parse horizon.
Babel 2.3.3 fixes this but breaks all python projects, the log-level log
files contain far too much content ;(

From https://github.com/python-babel/babel/issues/388:
* versions 2.3.0..2.3.2 break multiple -k/--keywords arguments for
  pybabel extract
* version 2.3.3 breaks the single -k/--keywords argument accepted by
  distutils extract_messages

Blacklist all these versions, and downgrade constraints.

Change-Id: Ia61e96963c0c81814d89c247c82fd75c6ab86a81
(cherry picked from commit 5a9ac571092d515d0de9ee9eee88b1b7878f9cc0)

commit_message:
change default ports for servers

Changing the recommended ports for Swift services
from ports 6000-6002 to unused ports 6200-6202;
so they do not conflict with X-Windows or other services.

Updated SAIO docs.

DocImpact
Closes-Bug: #1521339
Change-Id: Ie1c778b159792c8e259e2a54cb86051686ac9d18

commit_message:
Remove vpnaas code from devstack

This service is now configured by devstack plugin in master.

Change-Id: Ie5fc0d2a45c1b564f98c69ec9ea6fbdeeb465d32
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/devstack refs/changes/97/310897/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
deleted_lines: NEUTRON_VPNAAS_DIR=$DEST/neutron-vpnaas# Default provider for VPN service DEFAULT_VPN_PROVIDER=VPN:openswan:neutron_vpnaas.services.vpn.service_drivers.ipsec.IPsecVPNDriver:default Q_VPN_CONF_FILE=$NEUTRON_CONF_DIR/vpn_agent.ini# List of (optional) config files for VPN device drivers to use with # the neutron-q-vpn agent declare -a Q_VPN_EXTRA_CONF_FILES # VPN service plugin functions # ------------------------------------------- # Hardcoding for 1 service plugin for now source $TOP_DIR/lib/neutron_plugins/services/vpn function _determine_config_vpn { local cfg_file local opts="--config-file $NEUTRON_CONF --config-file=$Q_L3_CONF_FILE --config-file=$Q_VPN_CONF_FILE" if is_service_enabled q-fwaas; then opts+=" --config-file $Q_FWAAS_CONF_FILE" fi for cfg_file in ${Q_VPN_EXTRA_CONF_FILES[@]}; do opts+=" --config-file $cfg_file" done echo "$opts" } "neutron-vpn-agent") opts="$(_determine_config_vpn)" ;; if is_service_enabled q-vpn; then deprecated "Configuring q-vpn through devstack is deprecated" _configure_neutron_vpn fi if is_service_enabled q-vpn; then git_clone $NEUTRON_VPNAAS_REPO $NEUTRON_VPNAAS_DIR $NEUTRON_VPNAAS_BRANCH setup_develop $NEUTRON_VPNAAS_DIR fi elif is_service_enabled q-vpn; then run_process q-vpn "$AGENT_VPN_BINARY $(determine_config_files neutron-vpn-agent)" if is_service_enabled q-vpn; then neutron_vpn_stop fi if is_service_enabled q-vpn; then neutron_vpn_configure_agent fi function _configure_neutron_vpn { # Uses oslo config generator to generate VPNaaS sample configuration files (cd $NEUTRON_VPNAAS_DIR && exec ./tools/generate_config_file_samples.sh) if [ -f $NEUTRON_VPNAAS_DIR/etc/neutron_vpnaas.conf.sample ]; then cp $NEUTRON_VPNAAS_DIR/etc/neutron_vpnaas.conf.sample $NEUTRON_CONF_DIR/neutron_vpnaas.conf iniset $NEUTRON_CONF_DIR/neutron_vpnaas.conf service_providers service_provider $DEFAULT_VPN_PROVIDER fi neutron_vpn_install_agent_packages neutron_vpn_configure_common }

commit_message:
Restructure policy abstract driver

Change I5ff9c4e4b6d64750f5db2a73cc4317358aea0649 restructured the
identity subsystem. As part of the change, the abstract driver
was extracted to identity/backends/base.py

This change does the same for the policy subsystem.

Partial-Bug: 1563101
Change-Id: Id2a6e9d43724a7ffe95f097a9876b2320f8f01f8
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone refs/changes/79/307379/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from keystone.policy.backends import baseDriver = manager.create_legacy_driver(base.PolicyDriverV8)
deleted_lines: import abc import six@six.add_metaclass(abc.ABCMeta) class PolicyDriverV8(object): def _get_list_limit(self): return CONF.policy.list_limit or CONF.list_limit @abc.abstractmethod def enforce(self, context, credentials, action, target): """Verify that a user is authorized to perform action. For more information on a full implementation of this see: `keystone.policy.backends.rules.Policy.enforce` """ raise exception.NotImplemented() # pragma: no cover @abc.abstractmethod def create_policy(self, policy_id, policy): """Store a policy blob. :raises keystone.exception.Conflict: If a duplicate policy exists. """ raise exception.NotImplemented() # pragma: no cover @abc.abstractmethod def list_policies(self): """List all policies.""" raise exception.NotImplemented() # pragma: no cover @abc.abstractmethod def get_policy(self, policy_id): """Retrieve a specific policy blob. :raises keystone.exception.PolicyNotFound: If the policy doesn't exist. """ raise exception.NotImplemented() # pragma: no cover @abc.abstractmethod def update_policy(self, policy_id, policy): """Update a policy blob. :raises keystone.exception.PolicyNotFound: If the policy doesn't exist. """ raise exception.NotImplemented() # pragma: no cover @abc.abstractmethod def delete_policy(self, policy_id): """Remove a policy blob. :raises keystone.exception.PolicyNotFound: If the policy doesn't exist. """ raise exception.NotImplemented() # pragma: no cover Driver = manager.create_legacy_driver(PolicyDriverV8)

commit_message:
Pin the Django OpenStack Auth version

When using the v3 identity API, DOA 1.2.2 calls the keystone client
with a parameter that the keystone client doesn't support.

Pin the DOA version to 1.2.0 so that we avoid this incompatiblity
in Kilo installs.

Change-Id: Id0c2ed89f2edaddafac881340130b900adb87dc2
Closes-Bug: #1566455
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/requirements refs/changes/89/306089/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: django_openstack_auth==1.2.0,<1.3.0

commit_message:
Define identity interface - easy cases

The identity interface isn't adequately specified. Nobody could
implement an identity driver using the interface definition as it
is since they wouldn't know what the inputs are or the outputs.
We can't write a Manager using only the interface definition since
the definition is incomplete (For example it didn't even mention
that create_user returns the user).

Several tests are added specifically for the driver interface.
The driver was only tested through the manager, so we didn't have
tests that showed that the driver actually followed its interface,
just however the manager called it.

You might notice that the tests are missing some obvious cases
that should be tested. In some cases this is because the existing
drivers that we have (sql and ldap) don't work the same way. For
example, create_group on the sql driver always returns description
even when it's None while the ldap driver doesn't. I wanted to
keep this change simple and not modify the drivers. The interface
definition can be enhanced along with the drivers and these tests
can be added later.

There might be more requirements that the manager puts on the
drivers than what's documented/tested here. These can be added
later.

Change-Id: I9a9c660f2d98b6ac6cb032b40b32089cb5cf1844
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone refs/changes/50/291950/10 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: class IdentityDriverV8Tests(object): driver = None # subclasses must override driver to the actual driver. expect_is_domain_aware = True # Subclasses must override this to indicate whether it's domain-aware or # not. expected_default_assignment_driver = 'sql' # Subclasses must override this to the expected default assignment driver. expected_is_sql = False # Subclasses must override this to the expected is_sql value. expected_generates_uuids = True # Subclasses must override this to the expected expected_generates_uuids # value. def test_is_domain_aware(self): self.assertIs(self.expect_is_domain_aware, self.driver.is_domain_aware()) def test_default_assignment_driver(self): self.assertEqual(self.expected_default_assignment_driver, self.driver.default_assignment_driver()) def test_is_sql(self): self.assertIs(self.expected_is_sql, self.driver.is_sql) def test_generates_uuids(self): self.assertIs(self.expected_generates_uuids, self.driver.generates_uuids()) def test_create_user(self): user_id = uuid.uuid4().hex user = { 'id': user_id } self.driver.create_user(user_id, user)

commit_message:
Specify match_by in alarm-definition-update help message

Monasca cli - monasca help alarm-definition-update should
mention match_by instead of DIMENSION_KEY1,DIMENSION_KEY2 etc
This will help reduce confusion and will be more consistent
with monasca-api.

Change-Id: Icd7fe5a49bb25a90ae61cb7add63031ab0b9a5c7
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-monascaclient refs/changes/20/306520/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Full support of lifecycle for custom resources

This specification propose new API for custom resources and for
registration mapping for them.

Change-Id: I287a23dee52f7b9fd2a7051e8fee707567caafd1
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/heat-specs refs/changes/68/308468/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode =================================== Full lifecycle for custom resources =================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/heat/+spec/full-lifecycle-for-custom-resources New API for full lifecycle of Custom resources is necessary for Heat rigth now. Problem description =================== Currently Heat support custom mapping and custom resources types. "Custom resources" here are resources, which were provided via environments. Currently we store all these information in Database, but it's difficult to re-use again for another stacks. The good example is some custom resource, which combains Server + Volume + FloatingIP resources in one. If User wants to use this resource again he needs to have environment file and some file with custom resource template. Proposed change =============== The idea of this specification is to provide full API for Custom resources, which allows to: - upload custom resources templates in Heat DB - register mapping for these custom resources - update and delete custom resources Note:: Additional details will be added later after review and discussion with Heat core team. Alternatives ------------ None. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: skraynev Milestones ---------- Target Milestone for completion: newton-2 Work Items ---------- * TBD Dependencies ============ None.

subject: Fix Pecan singular collection controller lookups
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-04-05 06:21:23.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/26daba2a93f231a1f01ecd83c07438d7597339da', 'message': 'Fix Pecan singular collection controller lookups

The patch that added support for legacy controllers was checking to see if
a collection already had a plugin set for it.  It really needed to check if
there was a controller already set for that collection.

This also fixes the singular collection controller lookup.  Specifically,
the auto_allocate_topology extension has a URI of /auto-allocate-topology.
Normally, that level is a plural URI.

Change-Id: I2106cf01e1caefc817d6d27d5691452da730bb01
Closes-Bug: #1557519
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2016-04-05 22:08:29.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/38554128d2e59e3b8c14046cefc84566862402b9', 'message': 'Fix Pecan singular collection controller lookups

'}, {'number': 6, 'created': '2016-04-09 20:31:25.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/4126553413d5ad4bbaef49a3ec2ff8ab498c9c76', 'message': 'Fix Pecan singular collection controller lookups

Added get_pecan_controllers method to the auto_allocate_topology extension
so that the pecan controllers it uses are tailored specifically for that
extension.

Since the auto_allocated_topology is a singular collection, some extra
conditionals and handling were done to make the setting of plugins and
controllers correct.

Also, the patch that added support for legacy controllers was checking to see if
a collection already had a plugin set for it.  It really needed to check if
there was a controller already set for that collection.

Change-Id: I2106cf01e1caefc817d6d27d5691452da730bb01
Closes-Bug: #1557519
'}, {'number': 7, 'created': '2016-04-09 20:39:56.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/d37008baaffd5e3e52d68b064ddc1338b5476eda', 'message': 'Fix Pecan singular collection controller lookups

Added get_pecan_controllers method to the auto_allocate_topology extension
so that the pecan controllers it uses are tailored specifically for that
extension.

Since the auto_allocated_topology is a singular collection, some extra
conditionals and handling were done to make the setting of plugins and
controllers correct.

Also, the patch that added support for legacy controllers was checking to see if
a collection already had a plugin set for it.  It really needed to check if
there was a controller already set for that collection.

Change-Id: I2106cf01e1caefc817d6d27d5691452da730bb01

commit_message:
Fix Pecan singular collection controller lookups

Added get_pecan_controllers method to the auto_allocate_topology
extension so that the pecan controllers it uses are tailored
specifically for that extension.

Since the auto_allocated_topology is a singular collection, some extra
conditionals and handling were done to make the setting of plugins and
controllers correct.

Also, the patch that added support for legacy controllers was checking
to see if a collection already had a plugin set for it.  It really
needed to check if there was a controller already set for that
collection.

Change-Id: I2106cf01e1caefc817d6d27d5691452da730bb01
Closes-Bug: #1557519

added_lines: singular = _handle_plurals(collection) (hasattr(plugin, 'get_%s' % collection) or hasattr(plugin, 'get_%s' % singular))):def _handle_singular_uri_collection(singular_uri_collection): # NOTE(blogan): It may be possible to use attributes.REVERSED_PLURALS # for this, but its not populated until requests come in so instead of # possibly introducing odd bugs in the legacy API, we'll just loop through # the plurals only on startup. suc = singular_uri_collection.replace('-', '_') for (plural, singular) in attributes.PLURALS.items(): if suc == singular: return plural return singular_uri_collection # NOTE(blogan): This is mainly to handle the auto-allocate_topology # extension. It's URI is /auto-allocate-topology but its key in # the RESOURCE_ATTRIBUTE_MAP is auto_allocate_topologies collection = _handle_singular_uri_collection( ext_resource.collection) if manager.NeutronManager.get_controller_for_resource( collection): # NOTE(blogan): Since this does not have a controller, we know this
deleted_lines: hasattr(plugin, 'get_%s' % collection)): collection = ext_resource.collection if manager.NeutronManager.get_plugin_for_resource(resource): # NOTE(blogan): It is possible that a plugin is tied to the # collection rather than the resource. An example of this is # the auto_allocated_topology extension. All other extensions # created their legacy resources with the collection/plural form # except auto_allocated_topology. Making that extension # conform with the rest of extensions could invalidate this, but # it's possible out of tree extensions did the same thing. Since # the auto_allocated_topology resources have already been loaded # we definitely don't want to load them up with shim controllers, # so this will prevent that. if manager.NeutronManager.get_plugin_for_resource(collection): continue # NOTE(blogan): Since this does not have a plugin, we know this

commit_message:
network: Fix nova boot with multiple security-groups

Booting an instance with 'default' + other security-groups doesn't
apply the 'default' security-group on the instance.
Nova is required to remove the 'default' security-group from the request
to Neutron when it's the only security-group that should be applied on
the instance.
This bug is a result of change
I630008a9733624a9d9b59b7aa3b8b2a3f8985d61.

Closes-Bug: #1572171
Change-Id: I3eb685f4d82615d3ebd25e7471de47129c78c86a

commit_message:
Fix race between event write and thread processing

Journal rows are written in the pre-commit hook,
thus available only when the original operation (i.e. add port) commits.
In order to prevent race condition the journal triggering  was moved
from pre-commit to post-commit.

Change-Id: I0b52ccb43b405e7dd3d4f65066169a8bbee58c39
Closes-Bug: #1569986

commit_message:
ODL v2: Fix delay in sync pending rows

Fixed the delay in sync pending rows, so when "call_thread_on_end"
is called or thread timer is expired the thread will start the sync logic
with no delay.

Instead of starting the sync thread when it stops the thread will start
only once on the class initialization and will wait for event to be set.

Change-Id: I214c9372726e5e8cf333d8736c23332870377cbf
Closes-Bug: #1569923

documentation structure for the python-swiftclient.

commit_message:
Add new doc structure and contents for swiftclient

As a result of the Hackathon we have produced a new
documentation structure for the python-swiftclient.
This patch introduces the new structure and adds the
required content.

The intention is to document the CLI, the SwiftService
and Connection API. Importantly, we also provide
guidance on important considerations when using a swift
object store, such as which aspect of the python-swiftclient
to use for various use cases, common authentication patterns
and some useful examples.

Co-Authored-By: Alexandra Settle <alexandra.settle@rackspace.com>
Co-Authored-By: Mohit Motiani <mohit.motiani@intel.com>
Co-Authored-By: Hisashi Osanai <osanai.hisashi@jp.fujitsu.com>

Change-Id: I9eb41f8e9137efa66cead67dc264a76a3c03fbda

commit_message:
[docs-specs] UX personas spec

New spec to propose UX personas
in UI / UX section of the Contributor
Guide for Newton.

Change-Id: I1cb3c9084931f6400c560c2b16bd34afa9d9bbc1
Implements: blueprint ux-personas
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/docs-specs refs/changes/67/309567/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ============================================== Add UI content guidelines to Contributor Guide ============================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/openstack-manuals/+spec/ux-personas Add OpenStack personas within the OpenStack Documentation Contributor Guide under the UI guidelines section. Problem description =================== The OpenStack UX project is interested in adding a section to the OpenStack Documentation Contributor Guide that describes personas developed by the OpenStack UX project team. The personas could be applied to development design decisions, used as IA resources for evaluating requirements for new/changed guides, and in possible marketing collateral. The value of this effort is to help provide developers, designers, and reviewers with an improved awareness of OpenStack users to design and develop OpenStack with the appropriate audience goals, and resulting task flows, in mind. Personas help establish consistency across projects, create increased awareness for the customer and their goals, as well as, communicate differences between customers. Proposed change =============== In a new UX/UI section of the contributor guide, add a topic collection for personas. The personas section could be added as a peer to both the UI text guidelines (already exist) and to the (proposed) UI heuristic checklist section within the OpenStack Documentation Contributor Guide. Proposed table of contents: UX/UI guidelines (section title updated to reflect broader scope) * Value/Intro * UI text guidelines (already exist) * UI heuristic checklist (new, proposed in separate spec) * UX personas (new, proposed by this spec) In the personas section, the following personas will be ellaborated upon. Cloud Personas ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ The personas information will be based upon model companies and their ecosystems. They describe the cloud adoption stages and describe multiple roles defined with each company. Roles that perform similar tasks may be called something different in each company. It is also common for the same person to perform multiple roles or shared tasks. Early research shows that the role ecosystem is complex and diverse. Contact Piet Kruithof for the most recent version of the personas. Alternatives ------------ #. Do not add UX personas. #. Add personas, but create them in a new guide for UX design tools. An email was distributed to the doc project regarding the idea of a new UX design guide to house UX-related resources and tools for a cross-project audience. These were the options discussed in the email (sent 3/7/16). Please see email for more detail and history. Option A Create a OpenStack UX Design Guide: Tools for developers guide, under the Contributor Guides section on docs.openstack.org. The guide would house UX design materials, like engaging UX, personas, use cases, resources section with heuristic checklists, etc. Basically, creating a design corner concept with guide name tbd. * Pros: Peer to other contributor guides - creates a more prominent focus on UX/UI design in OpenStack, we could reference guide from appropriate locations to increase visibility * Cons: New guide-logistics more complicated, logistics help needed Takes longer to get reviews going. Option B Add to the existing Doc Contributor Guide, but modify the guide's scope. * Pros: Existing guide-logistics easier, content would be available to review sooner UI guidelines content in one location. The new UI heuristic checklist links to the UI text guidelines that we recently added to the doc contributor guide. * Cons: Not just for text guidelines anymore, so the guide's current scope would expand slightly to include a section specifically on UX/UI tools for a cross-project audience. Option C Add to the existing Doc Contributor Guide as-is, potentially adjust later. * Pros: Content available for review quickly, lowest logistical impact. * Cons: Scope could be confusing for users, adjusting later delays some work. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ~~~~~~~~~~~ Primary assignee: * pkruithofjr@gmail.com * stemke@us.ibm.com Other contributors: * gmolson@us.ibm.com * nancy.ann.michell@hpe.com * openstack@lanabrindley.com * rcresswe@cisco.com * jamielennox@gmail.com * jacalcat@us.ibm.com Work Items ~~~~~~~~~~ * Reach a consensus on new section's location and content structure. * Identify new topics to be created and submit content/reviews using the [blueprint ux-personas] tag. Dependencies ============ This work is a collaboration between the UX and Doc team that requires input from both projects. Testing ======= Testing will follow the standard documentation review process. References ========== * Discussion can occur using any official medium including IRC in #openstack-doc, the openstack-docs mailing list with [ux-personas] in the subject. .. _`documentation team meeting`: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Meetings/DocTeamMeeting

commit_message:
vpnaas: install apparmor before restarting the service

This plugin is not used in neutron-vpnaas gate since Liberty where we
use a devstack plugin. Sadly, the code is still used in Kilo gate of the
project.

This change will need to be backported up to kilo.

The change reflects the corresponding patch in neutron-vpnaas devstack

commit_message:
Tutorial for extending a workflow

Added tutorial for extending an existing workflow as a plugin.

Change-Id: I8e6af24b9d1dfe313e6ee6d43894d87d9c97068
Closes-Bug: #1511593
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/horizon refs/changes/07/244407/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines:
Extending an AngularJS Workflow =============================== A workflow extends the ``extensibleService``. This means that all workflows inherit properties and methods provided by the ``extensibleService``. Refer to inline documentation on what those properties and methods are. We highly recommend that you complete the :doc:``plugin tutorial `` if you have not done so already. If you do not know how to package and install a plugin, the rest of this tutorial will not make sense! In this tutorial, we will examine an existing workflow and how we can extend it as a plugin. Workflow Example ---------------- Below is an example of an existing workflow in Horizon. The goal is to inject our own custom step into this workflow. The most important take-away from this workflow is the list of steps. The extensible service will allow us to arbitrary inject our custom step into the ``steps`` array using id and a priority. :: (function() { 'use strict'; angular .module('horizon.dashboard.identity.users') .factory('horizon.dashboard.identity.users.actions.createWorkflowService', createWorkflow); createWorkflow.$inject = [ 'horizon.app.core.workflow.factory', 'horizon.dashboard.identity.basePath', 'horizon.framework.util.i18n.gettext' ]; function createWorkflow(workflowService, basePath, gettext) { var path = basePath + 'users/steps/'; var workflow = workflowService({ title: gettext('Create User'), btnText: { finish: gettext('Create User') }, steps: [ { id: 'details', title: gettext('User Details'), templateUrl: path + 'create-user/create-user.html', helpUrl: path + 'create-user/create-user.help.html', formName: 'createUsersForm' }, { id: 'projects', title: gettext('Select Projects'), templateUrl: path + 'select-projects/select-projects.html', helpUrl: path + 'select-projects/select-projects.help.html', formName: 'selectProjectsForm' } ] }); return workflow; } })(); File Structure -------------- Remember that the goal of this tutorial is to inject our custom step into an existing workflow. All of the files we are interested in resides in the ``static`` folder. myplugin enabled _31000_myplugin.py myplugin __init__.py panel.py static dashboard identity myplugin myplugin.js steps mystep.controller.js mystep.help.html mystep.html MANIFEST.in setup.py .. Note :: We no longer need ``view.py`` or ``templates`` because we are injecting into an existing workflow. The view is already provided in base Horizon. myplugin.js ----------- This is the entry point into our plugin. We hook into an existing module via the run block which is executed after the module has been initialized. All we need to do is inject it as a dependency and then use the methods provided in the extensible service to override or modify steps. In this example, we are going to prepend our custom step so that it will show up as the first step in the wizard. :: (function () { 'use strict'; angular .module('horizon.dashboard.identity.users') .run(bluePlugin); bluePlugin.$inject = [ 'horizon.dashboard.identity.basePath', 'horizon.dashboard.identity.users.actions.createWorkflowService' ]; function bluePlugin(basePath, workflow) { var path = basePath + 'users/steps/'; workflow.prepend({ title: gettext('Blue Step'), templateUrl: path + 'blue-step/blue-step.html', helpUrl: path + 'blue-step/blue-step.help.html', formName: 'blueStepForm' }); } })(); mystep.controller.js -------------------- In our controller, we have the ability to listen to events. It is important to note that the scope is the glue between our controllers - this is how we are propagating events from one controller to another. In this manner, actions we completed in the wizard are visually reflected in the table even though they are two completely different widgets. You can use the same mechanism to share data between the steps in your workflow. As long as your controllers are bound by the same parent scope, anything is possible. In this example, the events are broadcasted by the wizard and the user panel. Using $on method, we can listen to events generated by the wizard. We can even broadcast our own events via the $emit method. :: (function() { 'use strict'; angular .module('horizon.dashboard.identity.users') .controller('horizon.dashboard.identity.users.steps.blueStepController', blueStepController); blueStepController.$inject = [ '$scope', 'horizon.framework.widgets.wizard.events', 'horizon.dashboard.identity.users.events' ]; function blueStepController($scope, wizardEvents, userEvents) { $scope.$on(wizardEvents.ON_SWITCH, function(e, args) { console.info('Wizard is switching step!'); console.info(args); }); $scope.$on(wizardEvents.BEFORE_SUBMIT, function() { console.info('About to submit!'); }); $scope.$on(userEvents.createdUser, function(newUser) { console.info(newUser); }); } })(); mystep.help.html ---------------- In this tutorial, we will leave this file blank. Include additional information here if your step requires it. Otherwise, remove the file and the ``helpUrl`` property from your step. mystep.html ----------- This file contains contents you want to display to the user. We will provide a simple example of a step that asks for your favorite color. The most important thing to note here is the reference to our controller via the ``ng-controller`` directive. This is essentially the link to our controller. ::

Blue Plugin

My custom step
Place your custom content here!
Testing ------- Now that we have completed our plugin, lets package it and test that it works. Lastly, make sure that the panel containing the workflow you are extending is enabled (in this case, the identity users panel). Good luck! If you have questions, reach out to us in IRC!

commit_message:
Do not allow new creates for HIDDEN resources

Since HIDDEN is the last step in the resource deprecation process, we
should not allow creation of new stacks which contain HIDDEN resources.

blueprint: hidden-supportstatus-improvements
Change-Id: I6456667d97241045adaefdabacc270c2ac2256dc
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/heat refs/changes/60/249460/8 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def test_create_resource_hidden_support_status_disallowed(self): rname = 'test_res_id_none' tmpl = rsrc_defn.ResourceDefinition(rname, 'GenericResourceType') res = generic_rsrc.ResourceWithProps(rname, tmpl, self.stack) res.support_status.status = 'HIDDEN' res.id = 'test_res_id' exc = self.assertRaises(exception.ResourceFailure, scheduler.TaskRunner(res.create)) self.assertIn('Support status "HIDDEN" invalid for create', six.text_type(exc))

commit_message:
Provide driver in ODL for L2Gateway.

For more details on L2Gateway feature
present in OpenDaylight(ODL), please look here:
https://wiki.opendaylight.org/view/OVSDB:Hardware_VTEP

The L2Gateway API for Neutron spec is here:
https://github.com/openstack/networking-l2gw/blob/
  master/specs/kilo/l2-gateway-api.rst

This review depends on L2GW Service Driver
framework fix available here:
https://review.openstack.org/265692

Allow filtering by multiple severities

Filter by multiple severities using '|'
Ex. severity=LOW|MEDIUM

added_lines: import sixfrom designate.objects import PoolAttributeList "fast_ttl": "true", # The YAML Lib imports True as "1" - this is to catch all possible values TRUTHY_VALUES = ['TRUE', 1, '1', 'True', 'true', True] FALSEY_VALUES = ['FALSE', 0, '0', 'False', 'false', False] def filter(self, context, pools, zone): # Get list of requested attribute keys request_keys = set() request_values = {} for attr in zone.attributes: request_keys.add(attr.key) request_values[attr.key] = attr.value del_pools = set() for i in range(0, len(pools)): pool = pools[i] p_keys = set() p_values = {} for attr in pool.attributes: p_keys.add(attr.key) p_values[attr.key] = attr.value if not p_keys.issuperset(request_keys): del_pools.add(i) msg = "%(pool)s did not match list of requested attribute "\ "keys - removing from list. Requested: %(r_key)s. Pool:"\ "%(p_key)s" LOG.debug(msg, { 'pool': pool, 'r_key': request_keys, 'p_key': p_keys }) continue for key in six.iterkeys(request_values): LOG.debug("Checking value of %s for %s", key, pool) # Get around the wierd YAML import, and that attributes are # key: value text strings. if p_values[key] in self.TRUTHY_VALUES: p_values[key] = True if p_values[key] in self.FALSEY_VALUES: p_values[key] = False if request_values[key] in self.TRUTHY_VALUES: request_values[key] = True if request_values[key] in self.FALSEY_VALUES: request_values[key] = False if not p_values[key] == request_values[key]: del_pools.add(i) LOG.debug( "%(pool)s did not match requested value of %(key)s. " "Requested: %(r_val)s. Pool: %(p_val)s", { 'pool': pool, 'key': key, 'r_val': request_values[key], 'p_val': p_values[key], }) continue pool_list = [i for j, i in enumerate(pools) if j not in del_pools] pools = PoolAttributeList(objects=pool_list)

subject: Add connector info to volume_attachment table
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-02-25 18:49:11.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/8ca7ef02dba7412337c0a198a1306a7bdfc27a3b', 'message': "Add connector info to volume_attachment table

******************** WIP ***************************

Lots of work to get the unit tests sorted out still

Further cleanup/refinement in the the attach/detach methods
wouldn't hurt.

Revisit multi-attach plans, this patch should make it
a bit cleaner and easier to deal with going forward.

******************** WIP ***************************

A challenge we have with multi-attach and force-detach type operations is
having all of the needed connector info available to make the detach.

It turns out we have a mechanism for storing/keeping all of this, in fact
we have a few in use (volume_attachment table, volume table info, metadata...).

TLDR:
Store the connector info that is passed in during intiialize_connection
into a n attachment entry of the volume_attachment table.  We can then also
return the attachment_id to the caller so they can track and reference it as
needed (ie, future API calls send in the attachment ID to the detach method).

This patch just cleans up the initialize_connection and attach_volume methods.
Calls like begin_attach and attach should for the most part just be db updates
and callback methods.  The real *work* should be done in initialize_connection.
NOTE this change is just a foundation to clean up some the code we have and
doesn't change the behavior of any of the API's or how they're called.  Instead
we just fill in a complete volume_attachment entry instead of only parts of it
and we set a precedent that that table is a trusted resource.

Change-Id: I05f6afd3ad79d4164505543ac9bacdc7be802c2b

commit_message:
Add connector info to volume_attachment table

******************** WIP ***************************

Lots of work to get the unit tests sorted out still

Further cleanup/refinement in the the attach/detach methods
wouldn't hurt.

Revisit multi-attach plans, this patch should make it
a bit cleaner and easier to deal with going forward.

******************** WIP ***************************

A challenge we have with multi-attach and force-detach type operations is
having all of the needed connector info available to make the detach.

It turns out we have a mechanism for storing/keeping all of this, in fact
we have a few in use (volume_attachment table, volume table info, metadata...).

TLDR:
Store the connector info that is passed in during intiialize_connection
into a n attachment entry of the volume_attachment table.  We can then also
return the attachment_id to the caller so they can track and reference it as
needed (ie, future API calls send in the attachment ID to the detach method).

This patch just cleans up the initialize_connection and attach_volume methods.
Calls like begin_attach and attach should for the most part just be db updates
and callback methods.  The real *work* should be done in initialize_connection.
NOTE this change is just a foundation to clean up some the code we have and
doesn't change the behavior of any of the API's or how they're called.  Instead
we just fill in a complete volume_attachment entry instead of only parts of it
and we set a precedent that that table is a trusted resource.

Change-Id: I05f6afd3ad79d4164505543ac9bacdc7be802c2b

added_lines: def wait_for_zone_export_status(client, zone_export_id, status): """Waits for a exported zone to reach given status.""" LOG.info('Waiting for exported zone %s to reach %s', zone_export_id, status) _, zone_export = client.show_zone_export(zone_export_id) start = int(time.time()) while zone_export['status'] != status: time.sleep(client.build_interval) _, zone_export = client.show_zone_export(zone_export_id) status_curr = zone_export['status'] if status_curr == status: LOG.info('Exported Zone %s reached %s', zone_export_id, status) return if int(time.time()) - start >= client.build_timeout: message = ('Exported Zone %(zone_export_id)s failed to reach ' 'status=%(status) within the required time ' '(%(timeout)s s). Current ' 'status: %(status_curr)s' % {'zone_export_id': zone_export_id, 'status': status, 'status_curr': status_curr, 'timeout': client.build_timeout}) caller = misc_utils.find_test_caller() if caller: message = '(%s) %s' % (caller, message) raise lib_exc.TimeoutException(message)

commit_message:
Add specificaton for kubernetes integration

Implements: blueprint kuryr-k8s-integration
Change-Id: I855adc374ad935e58eebc9a01133d2909a7d3c4d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kuryr refs/changes/32/281132/6 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ==================================== Kuryr Kubernetes Integration ==================================== Include the URL of your launchpad RFE: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/kuryr/+spec/kuryr-k8s-integration This spec proposes how to integrate Kubernetes Bare Metal cluster with neutron network provider. Kubernetes is a platform for automating deployment, scaling and operations of application containers across clusters of hosts. There are already number of implementations of kubernetes network model, such as Flannel, Weave, Linux Bridge, OpenSwitch, Calico as well as other vendor implementations. Neutron already serves as a common way to support various networking providers via common API. Therefore, having neutron implementation of kubernetes network model, will enable different backend support in a common way. This approach provides clear benefit for operators who will have variety of networking choices that already supported via neutron. Problem Description =================== Application developer usually is not a networking engineer. He should be able to express the application intent. SDN (neutron via kuryr in our case) should be able to infer from the application intent how to provision the network. Kubernetes Overview ------------------- Kubernetes imposes some fundamental reachability requirements on the networking implementation: * All comnatiners can communicate without NAT. * All nodes can communicate with containers without NAT. * The IP the containers sees intesf is the same IP that others see. The kubernetes model is for each pod to have an IP in a flat shared namespace that allows full communication with physical computers and containers across the network. The above approach makes it easier than native Docker model to port applications from VMs to containers. Kubernetes model has the following API objects: * Namespace - serves as logical grouping of partition resources. Names of resources need to be unique within a namespace, but not across namespaces. * Pod - containing group of tightly coupled containers that share network namespace. * Replication Controller (RC) - ensures the requested number of pods. * Service - abstraction of endpoints, usually pods that implement a given service, defined by service selector. Service has service portal (VIP and port). Service IPs are only available inside the cluster. To receive traffic from the outside, it should be assigned external IP. Kubernetes two more powerful tools, labels and annotations. Both can be attached to the API objects. Labels are an arbitrary key/value pairs. Labels do not provide uniqueness. Annotations are string keys and values that can be used by external tooling to store arbitrary metadata. Use Cases --------- The kubernetes networking should address requirements of several stakeholders: 1. Application developer, the one that runs its application on the k8s cluster 2. Cluster administrator, the one that runs the k8s cluster 3. Network infrastructure administrator, the one that provides the physical network Use Case 1: Support current kubernetes network model that addresses application connectivity. Use Case 2: Application isolation policy support. This use case is about application isolation policy support as it is defined by kubernetes community, based on spec [1]. More enchanced use cases can be added in the future, that will allow to add extra functionality that is supported by neutron. Proposed Change =============== Model Mapping ------------- In order to support kubernetes networking via neutron, we should define how k8s model maps into neutron model. With regards to the first use case, to support native kubernetes networking mode, the mapping can be done in the following way: +-----------------+------------------+------------------------------------------------------+ | *k8s entity* | *neutron entity* | *notes* | +===========================================================================================+ |namespace | network | alternatively, each RC can be mapped into network | +-----------------+------------------+------------------------------------------------------+ |cluster subnet | subnet pool | subnet to allocate Pod IPs | +-----------------+------------------+------------------------------------------------------+ |portal net | subnet | VIP subnet, service VIP will be allocated from | +-----------------+------------------+------------------------------------------------------+ |external subnet | floating ip pool | To provide external access to services, each service | | | external network | should be assigned with external (floating IP) | | | router | router is required to enable north-south traffic | +-----------------+------------------+------------------------------------------------------+ |Pod | port | ports gets its IP from the cluster subnet pool | +-----------------+------------------+------------------------------------------------------+ |service | load balancer | each endpoint (pod) is a member in the load balancer | | | | pool. VIP is allocated from portal net subnet | +-----------------+------------------+------------------------------------------------------+ In order to support second use case, the application isolation policy mode, requested policy should be translated into corresponding security group. The security group should reflect the requested ACLs and be associated with pods that policy is applied to. TODO(irenab) add exact translation details Integration components ---------------------- There are two conceptual parts that kuryr need to support: First one is to listen to the kubernetes model changes. Based on the them, it should reflect kubernetes model in neutron. Second is to enable local network plugin on each worker node to automatically configure itself into proper virtual networks. Community Impact ---------------- This spec invites community to collaborate on unified solution to support kubernetes networking by using neutron as a backend via Kuryr. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- TBD Work Items ---------- TBD References ========== [1] https://docs.google.com/document/d/1blfqiH4L_fpn33ZrnQ11v7LcYP0lmpiJ_RaapAPBbNU/edit#)

commit_message:
libvirt: remove version checks for PCI device detach

The PCI device detach code relies on the libvirt device
remove event added in libvirt 1.1.1 which is older than
our min required libvirt. Thus we can remove the version
checks for this feature.

Change-Id: I3fffeb65eb74535e1266feb8b03fea91a130bfc6

commit_message:
Change undercloud update instructions

Update of overcloud nodes should follow right after undercloud update.
The reason is that new templates may expect features included in
newer packages installed on overcloud nodes (for example new puppet
class definitions). Also adds note about having to explicitly use
default environment registry file - otherwise some resource definitions
may be missing.

Change-Id: I34d8826edc9efe248ab82e36cb1d40914fa9dca4

commit_message:
Wrong mocks, wrong mock order

This test was mocking the wrong driver (virt.driver.ComputeDriver vs.
virt.fake.SmallFakeDriver), so the test wasn't actually ever hitting
that mock; just mock self.compute.driver instead so we don't have to
care which one it is.

This test also had the mock args in the wrong order (decorators are
applied from the bottom upwards), but that doesn't matter now that there
is only one decorator at the method definition level (the other is now a
context manager mock).

The DB mock was wrong too (nova.db.api vs nova.db). It should have been
called when you commented out the following logic that is was testing,
but it isn't. That mock should probably be at the object level anyway,
changing it to mock objects.InstanceList.get_by_filters instead.

            if len(driver_uuids) == 0:
                # Short circuit, don't waste a DB call
                return objects.InstanceList()

Change-Id: I02db1afbeb9c60c4c601e92e41cad053f52cb1b7

signify the relationship.

commit_message:
Add ALIAS records to designate objects

This adds the initial ALIAS object recordsets.

Note: The RECORD_TYPE value is set to `260` to be in line with
      PowerDNS, the single DNS server that we know that supports
      ALIAS records natively.

Change-Id: Idf843c77ef7c383e5296114c23459608853693bc
