commit_message:
Add ALIAS support in central and zone manager

The API can now accept an ALIAS record and central will properly
handle creating the A record by way of the zone manager task. The
periodic has not been configured just yet.

Depends-On: I02ed90d3e7f64bbd5e9acc8133dce0b7e0e560e2
Change-Id: I63842459b3c1fb9280f614c2738e0e8ea7a33dba
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/designate refs/changes/94/247194/10 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import socketfrom designate.objects import adapters from designate.objects import RecordSet from designate.central import rpcapi as central_rpcapi from designate.pool_manager import rpcapi as pool_manager_rpcapifrom designate.zone_manager import alias RPC_API_VERSION = '1.1' def __init__(self, threads=None, storage_obj=None, quota_manager=None): self.storage = storage_obj or storage.get_storage(storage_driver) self.quota = quota_manager or quota.get_quota() return central_rpcapi.CentralAPI.get_instance() @property def pool_manager_api(self): return pool_manager_rpcapi.PoolManagerAPI.get_instance() LOG.info('Periodic tasks: %s', enabled) LOG.info('All Periodic Tasks: %s', tasks.PeriodicTask.get_extensions(None)) def flatten_alias_record(self, context, domain_id, recordset): return alias.flatten( context, self.central_api, domain_id, recordset ) def delete_alias_record(self, context, domain_id, recordset): return alias.delete( context, self.central_api, domain_id, recordset )
deleted_lines: from designate.central import rpcapi RPC_API_VERSION = '1.0' def __init__(self, threads=None): self.storage = storage.get_storage(storage_driver) self.quota = quota.get_quota() return rpcapi.CentralAPI.get_instance()

commit_message:
Add ALIAS records to designate objects

This adds the initial ALIAS object recordsets.

Note: The RECORD_TYPE value is set to `260` to be in line with
      PowerDNS, the single DNS server that we know that supports
      ALIAS records natively.

Change-Id: I7451931bdb9cc80bccca8c12ec2e9510c35a1287

commit_message:
Add ALIAS record flattening zone manager task

This implements a zone manager task that flattens an ALIAS record
to the downstream A record values.

Depends-On: I7451931bdb9cc80bccca8c12ec2e9510c35a1287
Change-Id: I26dff77c22f964ada0100c36e92e848b4667ab0e

added_lines: # Copyright 2015 Rackspace Inc. # # Author: Eric Larson <eric.larson@rackspace.com> # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import unittest import socket import mock from designate.zone_manager import alias from designate import exceptions class TestALIASRecordFlattener(unittest.TestCase): def setUp(self): self.context = mock.Mock() self.central_api = mock.Mock() self.zone_id = 1234 self.recordset = mock.Mock() self.storage = mock.Mock() self.flattener = alias.ALIASRecordFlattener( self.context, self.central_api, self.zone_id, self.recordset, self.storage ) def test_init_allows_managed_records(self): assert self.context.edit_managed_records is True def test_get_record_obj(self): self.flattener.get_record_obj(1234) self.storage.get_record.assert_called_with(self.context, 1234) @mock.patch.object(alias, 'dns') def test_find_record_target_ips_success(self, dns): result = self.flattener.find_record_target_ips('foo.com.') dns.resolver.query.assert_called_with('foo.com.', 'A') assert result == [r.address for r in dns.resolver.query()] @mock.patch.object(alias, 'dns') def test_find_record_target_ips_nxdomain(self, dns): dns.resolver.query.side_effect = [dns.resolver.NXDOMAIN] result = self.flattener.find_record_target_ips('foo.com.') assert result == [] @mock.patch.object(alias, 'dns') def test_find_record_target_ips_socket_error(self, dns): dns.resolver.query.side_effect = [socket.gaierror] result = self.flattener.find_record_target_ips('foo.com.') assert result == [] def test_create_recordlist_from_record(self): alias_record = mock.Mock(data='foo.com.', id='1234') self.flattener.find_record_target_ips = mock.Mock() self.flattener.find_record_target_ips.return_value = [ '192.168.1.1', '192.168.1.2' ] a_records = self.flattener.create_recordlist_from_record(alias_record) assert len(a_records) == 2 assert a_records[0].data == '192.168.1.1' assert a_records[1].data == '192.168.1.2' assert a_records[0].managed assert a_records[0].managed_resource_type == 'ALIAS' assert a_records[0].managed_resource_id == '1234' @mock.patch.object(alias, 'objects') def test_update_recordset(self, objects): alias_record = mock.Mock( data='foo.com.', id='1234', name='foo zone', ) self.flattener.find_record_target_ips = mock.Mock() self.flattener.find_record_target_ips.return_value = [ '192.168.1.1', '192.168.1.2' ] self.flattener.create_recordset(alias_record) records = self.flattener.create_recordlist_from_record(alias_record) objects.RecordSet.assert_called_with( name=self.recordset.name, type='A', ttl=3600, # TODO(elarson): This should be from the upstream A record(s) records=records, visible='mdns' ) self.central_api.create_recordset.assert_called_with( self.context, self.zone_id, objects.RecordSet() ) def test_existing_recordset_found(self): result = self.flattener.existing_recordset() assert result self.central_api.find_recordset.assert_called_with( self.context, criterion={ 'zone_id': self.zone_id, 'type': 'A' } ) def test_existing_recordset_not_found(self): self.central_api.find_recordset.side_effect = exceptions.RecordSetNotFound() result = self.flattener.existing_recordset() assert result is None def test_find_serial(self): serial = self.flattener.find_serial() self.central_api.get_zone.assert_called_with( self.context, self.zone_id ) assert serial == self.central_api.get_zone().serial def test_flatten_record_create(self): self.flattener.existing_recordset = mock.Mock(return_value=None) self.flattener.create_recordset = mock.Mock() self.flattener.flatten_record('foo') self.flattener.create_recordset.assert_called_with('foo') def test_flatten_record_update(self): self.flattener.existing_recordset = mock.Mock(return_value='original') self.flattener.update_recordset = mock.Mock() self.flattener.flatten_record('foo') self.flattener.update_recordset.assert_called_with('original', 'foo') def test_flatten(self): record = mock.Mock(name='foo.com', data='bar.com.') self.recordset.records = [record] self.flattener.flatten_record = mock.Mock() self.flattener.flatten() self.flattener.flatten_record.assert_called_with(record) def test_delete(self): recordset = mock.Mock() self.flattener.existing_recordset = mock.Mock( return_value=recordset ) self.flattener.delete() self.central_api.delete_recordset.assert_called_with( self.context, self.zone_id, recordset.id ) def test_delete_noop_when_not_exists(self): self.flattener.existing_recordset = mock.Mock(return_value=None) self.flattener.delete() assert not self.central_api.delete_recordset.called class TestALIASEntryFunctions(unittest.TestCase): @mock.patch.object(alias, 'ALIASRecordFlattener') def test_flatten(self, flattener_class): alias.flatten('foo') # Ensure we pass though *args flattener_class.assert_called_with('foo') assert flattener_class().flatten.called @mock.patch.object(alias, 'ALIASRecordFlattener') def test_delete(self, flattener_class): alias.delete('foo') # Ensure we pass though *args flattener_class.assert_called_with('foo') assert flattener_class().delete.called

commit_message:
Update database and add ALIAS record support

This includes the visibility aspects of ALIAS support. No actual ALIAS
records can be submitted just yet. There is also a comment in the
recordset API to use only `api` visible records.

Also, SQLAlchemy converts enums to varchar and doesn't seem to pass
along all args (ie `default`) to the varchar. Therefore I had to make
the visible column nullable.

Depends-On: I26dff77c22f964ada0100c36e92e848b4667ab0e
Change-Id: I02ed90d3e7f64bbd5e9acc8133dce0b7e0e560e2

added_lines: # Copyright (c) 2015 Rackspace Hosting # # Author: Eric Larson <eric.larson@rackspace.com> # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. from oslo_log import log as logging from sqlalchemy import Column, MetaData, Table, Enum from migrate.changeset.constraint import UniqueConstraint VISIBLE_TYPES = ['all', 'mdns', 'api'] LOG = logging.getLogger(__name__) meta = MetaData() def upgrade(migrate_engine): # Upgrade operations go here. Don't create your own engine; bind # migrate_engine to your metadata meta.bind = migrate_engine recordsets_table = Table('recordsets', meta, autoload=True) dialect = migrate_engine.url.get_dialect().name using_sqlite = dialect.startswith('sqlite') if dialect.startswith('postgresql'): with migrate_engine.connect() as conn: conn.execution_options(isolation_level='AUTOCOMMIT') conn.execute( "ALTER TYPE recordset_types ADD VALUE 'ALIAS' " "AFTER 'SOA'") conn.close() if not dialect.startswith('sqlite'): # sqlite just uses a varchar instead, so we don't need to do # anything about it. type_col = recordsets_table.c.type record_types = list(type_col.type.enums) record_types.append('ALIAS') recordsets_table.c.type.alter( type=Enum(name='recordset_types', *record_types) ) # Re-add constraint for sqlite if dialect.startswith('sqlite'): constraint = UniqueConstraint('domain_id', 'name', 'type', name='unique_recordset', table=recordsets_table) constraint.create() # Add visible column recordsets_visible_col = Column( 'visible', Enum(name='visibility', *VISIBLE_TYPES), default='all', nullable=using_sqlite ) recordsets_visible_col.create(recordsets_table) def downgrade(migrate_engine): meta.bind = migrate_engine recordsets_table = Table('recordsets', meta, autoload=True) recordsets_table.c.visible.drop() dialect = migrate_engine.url.get_dialect().name if not dialect.startswith('sqlite'): # Update our types column with ALIAS type recordset_types_col = recordsets_table.c.type record_types = list(recordset_types_col.enums) record_types.pop(record_types.index('ALIAS')) recordset_types_col.alter( type=Enum('record_types', *record_types) )

commit_message:
Move OpenStack client to test-requirements

OpenStack client is not a runtime dependency of heatclient,
and having it in requirements just brings in many unneeded dependencies.

Move it to test-requirements so unit tests for osc plugin work.

Change-Id: I425b33d5e97e9328fe440f6b190bdd6b6cc813bf
Closes-Bug: #1562023

commit_message:
Add new probabilistic placement algorithm.

Add a new placement algorithm that builds a probablity distribution from
weights and chooses a host by sampling from that distribution.

blueprint probabilistic-weighted-placement-algorithm

Change-Id: Ib30f0ebf5db5d5e194a11d28f278fa30703cff4b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/39/293139/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ========================================== Probabablistic weighted placment algorithm ========================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/probabalistic-weighted-placement-algorithm When running multiple active schedulers in Nova, repeated failures are seen to schedule instances. This is because the schedulers have an inconsistent view of compute node resource usage. This specification describes a new placement algorithm to alleviate this issue. Problem description =================== Currently when running multiple schedulers in Nova many failures are seen to schedule instances. Because of their inconsistent knowledge of the compute node resources they tend to overload the 'best' node, unaware that other schedulers have already placed instances there. Nova already has an option to help with this issue. The ``scheduler_host_subset_size`` option enables the scheduler to place instances randomly from the best N hosts. However, this option comes without any guidance about what it should be set to for a given deployment or number of schedulers. It may also not be the optimal algorithm for reducing scheduling failure. Use Cases --------- Very large openstack deployments wish to run multiple active schedulers. This is not only for availablility but also request scaling purposes. When running multiple schedulers they would like to see a low level of failures when scheduling instances. Proposed change =============== The current algorithm for placement works in the following manner::: weighed_hosts = weigh_hosts(available_host_list) weighed_hosts.sort() random.choice(weighed_hosts[:n]) It chooses randomly (equal probablilities) from the top ``n`` weighted hosts. ``n`` is set to the ``scheduler_host_subset_size`` option. The proposed algorithm follows:: weighted_hosts = weigh_hosts(available_host_list) host_probabilities = build_cdf_from_weights(weighted_hosts) pick_from_distribution(host_probablilties) Instead of choosing randomly from the top ``n`` hosts the algorithm will assign a probablility of being chosen to **every** host based on its weight. If a host has twice the weight of another it will be given twice the probablitiy of being chosen. The host list will form a proper probability distribution: the sum of all probabilites across hosts will be 1. A proof of concept for this change is avialable on Gerrit. [1]_ Alternatives ------------ The main alternative to this change is to reduce the inconsistency of the resource usage between scheduler instances. There is ongoing work in this area in Nova already. However considering that we are in a distributed environment some inconsistency will always be expected if we are to maintain a high request throughput. TODO - Describe some of the other attempts to improve this issue. (Generally via reducing scheduler inconsistency) Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- None Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ We are hopeful that a performance improvement will be seen in terms of a reduction of the number of failures to schedule that are seen. A simple local simulation has been run using threads that mimics the current Nova algorithms. [2]_ The simulation ran with the following parameters: * Number of compute nodes = 100 * Max instances per compute node = 10 * Attempted number of placements = 5000 * Number of concurrent schedulers = 10 When running with the current algorithm the following number of failures were seen for different values of ``n`` the ``scheduler_host_subset_size`` +-------------+---------------+ | N | Num Failures | +=============+===============+ | 1 (default) | 404 | +-------------+---------------+ | 10 | 115 | +-------------+---------------+ | 50 | 93 | +-------------+---------------+ | 100 | 544 | +-------------+---------------+ When running the simulation with the proposed changes the number of failures seen was 9. This is an order of magnitued better than even the best value for ``scheduler_host_subset_size``. Although this simulation is simple it provides some indication that a performance improvement will be seen. The single request performance of the scheduler should not be affected. The current algorithm needs a sorted list of hosts to pick from the top ``n``. Building a probablility distribution means that sorting the list is not required, and the extra work of building the distribution should not be overly computationally intensive. The single request performance of the scheduler is not dominated by in-memory computations. Other deployer impact --------------------- Config option will be added to enable the new placement algorithm (``host_weights_distribution_placement``). The default value will be set to ``False`` which should be suitable for small deployments. Deployers will be advised to set to ``True`` in a multi scheduler environment. Those upgrading would see no difference in their deployment until this option is enabled. Developer impact ---------------- None - Some API additions made to ``weights`` API, but custom ``BaseWeighers`` should not be affected. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: <mjdoffma@us.ibm.com> Other contributors: None Work Items ---------- * Modify the ``weights`` API to return values needed to calculate the CDF. * Create the new placement algorithm. Write functions required to generate a probablity distribution from a weighted list of hosts. Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= * Detailed unit testing of probablity distribution generation. * Unit tests added to ``weights`` API. * Unit tests added to filter scheduler for new algorithm. Documentation Impact ==================== Documentation will be generated for new options. Documentation about running multiple schedulers must be updated. References ========== .. [1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/287397/ .. [2] TODO put simulation code up on Github and link here. History ======= .. list-table:: Revisions :header-rows: 1 * - Release Name - Description * - Newton - Introduced

commit_message:
JSON schema for notifications

Versioned notifications has a well defined schema implemented with
versioned objects. This schema prevents nova from changing the
structure of the notification without communicating the change to
the notification consumers. This communication is done via the version
number embedded into the notification payload. However this communication
is limited and does not contain information about what is changed in the
schema or what is the the structure of a new notification.

Change-Id: I185708f9d81f809c02f5a32f6896bc20946a0002
Implements: bp json-schema-for-notifications
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/54/304454/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ============================= JSON schema for notifications ============================= Include the URL of your launchpad blueprint: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/json-schema-for-notifications Versioned notifications has a well defined schema implemented with versioned objects. This schema prevents nova to change the structure of the notification without communicating the change with the notification consumers. This communication is done via the version number embedded into the notification payload. However this communication is limited and does not contains information about what is changed in the schema or what is the the structure of a new notification. Problem description =================== Notification consumers can understand the structure of the notification payload based on notification samples or based on the nova internal object model only. If a notification payload is changed then the internal object model is updated and a new sample file is added. However the sample information is hard to consume from software and the consumer shall not depend on the nova internal object model directly. Therefore a notification change means that the consumer needs manual work to adapt to the change. Also the consumer does not have an independent and automatic way to ensure that the received notification has the expected structure without trying to consume it. Use Cases --------- I as a notification consumer want to have a way to see the structure of the notification payload without looking into the nova internal object model or using human intelligence to understand the notification sample, so that I can further automate the consumption of the new or changed notifications. I as a notification consumer want to validate that the received notification has the defined structure automatically so that I can be sure my software can consume the notification properly and detect problems earlier. Proposed change =============== Notification payload is a json blob therefore it is natural to define the structure of this json blob with a json schema [1]. This way there would be a nova implementation independent, machine readable description of the notification payload that the notification consumer software can use to understand and validate the received notification. Therefore this spec proposes to add json schema for every versioned notification in Nova. Alternatives ------------ As an alternative it would be possible to externalize the nova internal object model used to define the notifications and offer it as a python library to consumers. However this would only help consumer that are capable of import python libraries and it would force the consumers to depend on oslo versioned objects. Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- None Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- A json schema is added for every existing versioned notification and it will be mandatory to add schema for every new notification in the future. A generic code is added to the versioned notification framework that validates that the notification being emitted is consistent with the stored json schema. Other end user impact --------------------- Notification consumer can use the provided json schema to validate received notification but it is not mandatory. Performance Impact ------------------ None Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- Developers changing or adding new notifications to Nova needs to define the schema of the payload. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: balazs-gibizer Work Items ---------- * Add json schema to the exiting versioned notifications. * Add code to the versioned notification framework that validates the notification upon emission. * Add test to make sure every new or changed notification has a proper schema stored in Nova. Dependencies ============ As the versioned notification transformation work [2] is progressing more and more legacy notification will be transformed to versioned notification format which means more and more notification needs the schema to be added. Testing ======= The existing unit and functional test environment is enough to fully cover the changes introduced by this spec. Documentation Impact ==================== The notifications developer doc [3] needs to be updated. References ========== * [1] http://json-schema.org/ * [2] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/286675/ * [3] http://docs.openstack.org/developer/nova/notifications.html History ======= .. list-table:: Revisions :header-rows: 1 * - Release Name - Description * - Newton - Introduced

commit_message:
Angular direct service access.

Angular based Horizon widgets and Horizon plugins will want to
contact OpenStack API's directly to enable much more responsive UI
and to place less load on the Horizon servers by proxying service
calls through horizon proxies.

Change-Id: I612c6bfefa8e157f7219938bb3e82896dde8fa09

commit_message:
Add dependencies for paramiko 2.0

Paramiko version 2.0 has been released. It now uses the Python library
cryptography. Installing this requires additional system packages. This
commit adds in the appropriate packages required by cryptography based
on its documentation [1].

An alternative approach would have been to constrain the version of
Paramiko however the project describes the 1.x versions as relying on
insecure dependencies [2].

The apt packages autoconf and g++ are removed because they are
dependencies of build-essential.

[1] https://cryptography.io/en/latest/installation/
[2] http://www.paramiko.org/installing.html

Change-Id: Ia7e0d64214cfd5412ec236ee4bdd6a076821d258

commit_message:
Pylint: refactor ignored message lists

The way these are organized makes it rather hard to
associate comments and their messages, and makes it
more work to modify this list in a meaningful way (or
re-use it for a project like os-brick).

Move things around a bit to make this easier to manage.

Change-Id: Ieebca9f97f6b15832693a37fa03f97c1074d64e8

commit_message:
Fix ControllerExtraConfig parameter name

We've had a typo for a while that a parameter is named
"controllerExtraConfig" with lowercase c, which can be quite confusing
for users because the other similar parameters
(e.g. NovaComputeExtraConfig) consistently start with an upper case
letter.

We'll support both variants from now on, marking the typoed variant as
deprecated.

Change-Id: Ic67a4297e7fa08308889b95ba35389a01f70f5a4

deleted_lines: Controller specific configuration to inject into the cluster. Same structure as ExtraConfig. ControllerExtraConfig: {get_param: controllerExtraConfig}

commit_message:
Fix values for root plugin attributes

Currently root plugin attributes values inconsistent with
specific plugin version attributes provided by client. This patch
fills plugin attributes with proper values for specific plugin version.

Change-Id: I1c85d6e080f8fd16d5b65c1bf670fdfb3ba0ff1b
Closes-Bug: #1573440
(cherry picked from commit cea2d5cc55de724fd9262803ca7472b0c59644ba)

commit_message:
Add a No Prior Key Certificate Order Type

Current Barbican TLS certificate order types require clients to provide
a CSR or a previously-stored public key. However, some use cases (such
as automated device provisioning) require Barbican to generate the
private/public/CSR information and then to create the certificate. This
blueprint proposes adding this 'generate-key' order type.

Change-Id: I9a2c4d7a7166f6bf8cc2d8eb0fb235ea23d9d68f
Implements: blueprint api-order-certificate-add-no-prior-key-type
APIImpact: Adds a new certificate order metadata type to /v1/orders
DocImpact: Update orders resource docs to mention the new type

This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ========================================= Add a No Prior Key Certificate Order Type ========================================= https://blueprints.launchpad.net/barbican/+spec/api-order-certificate-add-no-prior-key-type Problem Description =================== Current Barbican TLS certificate order types require clients to provide a CSR or a previously-stored public key. However, some use cases (such as automated device provisioning) require Barbican to generate the private/public/CSR information and then to create the certificate. This blueprint proposes adding this 'no prior key' order type. Proposed Change =============== We propose adding a new order metadata type to the current Barbican certificate order type that does not require specifying a Certificate Signing Request (CSR) or a public key. The overall order request would then appear as follows (borrowing from Ade's Certificate API spec [1]):: { "type": "certificate", "meta": { "ca": "CA identifier (optionally, see note in reference [2] below)", "request_type": "no-prior-key", "subject_dn": "subject DN (RFC1485 [3])" "extensions": "base 64 DER encoded ASN.1 values (RFC 5280)" "requestor_name": "(optional) string" "requestor_email": "(optional) email address - RFC 5322, 5321" "requestor_phone" : "(optional) string" } } Extensions data defined by the following in RFC 5272 (section 3.1), where the specific ASN.1 structures for each extension are defined in RFC 5280 (section 4.2) [4]: Extensions ::= SEQUENCE SIZE (1..MAX) OF Extension Extension ::= SEQUENCE { extnID OBJECT IDENTIFIER, critical BOOLEAN DEFAULT FALSE, extnValue OCTET STRING -- contains the DER encoding of an ASN.1 value -- corresponding to the extension type identified -- by extnID } To process this order type, Barbican would first create a private/public key pair, and then the PKCS10 request. This along with the order metadata above would be passed to the certificate plugin to initiate the certificate ordering process. Alternatives ------------ None, as the proposed approach simply builds on top of the certificate order processes already established via [1]. Data model impact ----------------- None. REST API impact --------------- See above in proposed changes. Security impact --------------- None. Notifications & Audit Impact ---------------------------- None, other than additional audit changes needed. Other end user impact --------------------- There will need to be changes in either barbican-client or certmonger to support the new API. Performance Impact ------------------ None. Other deployer impact --------------------- None. Developer impact ---------------- None. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) Primary assignee: TBD Work Items ---------- * Modify API code to parse the new Order parameters and pass the data to lower levels. * Add code to validate request data. * Add code to certificate_manger.py to send the requests to the plugins. Modify the plugin interface contract to provide default implementations. * Add client code. Dependencies ============ This work should do done after the revamped certificate order processing in [1] has introduced the order metadata type concept to the code base. Testing ======= More unit and functional tests will be needed. Documentation Impact ==================== Docs (including sphinx and plugin docs) will need to be changed to reflect this API. References ========== [1] http://specs.openstack.org/openstack/barbican-specs/specs/kilo/certificate-order-api.html [2] http://specs.openstack.org/openstack/barbican-specs/specs/kilo/identify-cas.html [3] http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc1485 A string representation of distinguished names [4] http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc5280 Internet X.509 Public Key Infrastructure Certificate and Certificate Revocation List (CRL) Profile

commit_message:
Add to Orders API Support to Reissue Certificates

This blueprint adds to Barbican the ability to reissue a X.509
certificate. After a certificate is issued via a Barbican 'certificate'
order (which produces a certificate in Barbican with a unique UUID), it
should then be possible to create another Barbican order to reissue a
certificate by providing the UUID of the original certificate. The
original order information could then be used for the new order,
including the original certificate information and ordering information
specific to the certificate authority (CA) that issued the certificate
originally.

Change-Id: I0968b8c010f348a783413b9bc3c71b7794571dfb
Implements: blueprint api-order-ssl-add-reissue-support
APIImpact: Adds a new certificate order type to /v1/orders
DocImpact: Update orders resource and plugin docs to mention the new type

added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ===================================================== Add to Orders API Support to Reissue SSL certificates ===================================================== Include the URL of your launchpad blueprint: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/barbican/+spec/api-order-ssl-add-reissue-support This blueprint adds to Barbican the ability to reissue an SSL certificate. After an SSL certificate is issued via a Barbican 'certificate' order (which produces a certificate in Barbican with a unique UUID), it should then be possible to create another Barbican order to reissue a certificate by providing the UUID of the original certificate. The original order information could then be used for the new order, including the original certificate information and ordering information specific to the certificate authority (CA) that issued the certificate originally. Problem Description =================== An issued certificate may need to be reissued in the future, such as due to a lost or compromised private key, or else the customer needs to change information about the original certificate such as a sub-domain. It would be helpful for Barbican to support reissuing certificates by referring to a certificate previously created via Barbican. Information from that existing certificate and its associated order could then be used for the reissue certificate process, including the original CA order ID if needed. Proposed Change =============== The proposal is to add a new order type called 'certificate-reissue' that accepts the same order metadata as for the 'certificate' type, with the addition of a required 'container_ref' attribute that refers to an existing certificate-type container. Ade's Common Certificate API spec [1] provides more detail on the metadata formats available. As part of worker reissue certificate processing, a new method is added to the certificate event plugin contract called 'notify_reissue_certificate_is_starting()' to indicate that the reissue process is beginning. This allows for enterprises to perform business activities such as creating a customer ticket to track the process of the reissue process. The worker flow then invokes a new method on the certificate plugin contract called 'reissue_certificate_request()'. This new method compares the current order's information with the original order's information to determine what information needs to be modified on the certificate, and then can work with a certificate authority (CA) to reissue the certificate. This original order information is found from the provided container reference, per woodster's proposed specification for adding an order reference to generated containers and secrets [2]. Similar to the certificate issuance workflow, the 'reissue_certificate_request()' method on the certificate plugin can either return a new certificate or else call for a retry of the CA status update method in the future. The new certificate information is added to a new certificate container, and a new method is called on the certificate event plugin called 'notify_reissue_certificate_is_ready()' to indicate that a new certificate is generated. The original certificate container is not be expired or deleted as clients may operate with the old and new certificates until affected devices can be updated. Alternatives ------------ None. Data model impact ----------------- None. REST API impact --------------- Same as for [1], with the addition of a 'container_ref' attribute to the order metadata. Security impact --------------- None. Notifications & Audit Impact ---------------------------- New events will be issued as detailed above. Other end user impact --------------------- This proposal requires adding support for the new order type to the Barbican Python client. Performance Impact ------------------ None. Other deployer impact --------------------- None. Developer impact ---------------- None. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: TBD Other contributors: john-wood-w Work Items ---------- * Add validation to API code to verify container_ref is provided. * Add new methods to certificate and certificate event plugins. * Modify certificate_manager.py to handle new reissue workflow orchestration. * Modify plugin supports() method to handle new reissue type. * Modify client code to support new feature. * Add functional testing for this new feature, similar to that used for testing the issue certificate flows. Dependencies ============ The code changes for accepted blueprint [1] and proposed blueprint [2] are required for this blueprint. Testing ======= New unit and functional tests of this new certificate order type will be required. Documentation Impact ==================== Docs (including sphinx and plugin docs) will need to be changed to reflect this API. References ========== [1] http://specs.openstack.org/openstack/barbican-specs/specs/kilo/certificate-order-api.html [2] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/147267/

commit_message:
Security Utilities for fuzz tests

This file contains helper methods used for security fuzz tests. It
generates datasets that can be used in parameterized test cases, and
verifies responses to API requests to ensure that they do not contain
indicators of vulnerability.

Change-Id: Ic4174d595fb89652127128c1a95c36c60e408fdd

import json import re import urllib class Fuzzer(object): def __init__(self, default_fuzz_type='junk'): self.default_fuzz_type = default_fuzz_type self.types = [ 'sqli', 'xss', 'xml', 'json', 'ascii', 'unicode', 'content_types', 'huge', 'junk', 'json_recursion', 'date', 'bad_numbers', 'bad_urls', 'traversal', 'rce' ] self.named_types = [ 'content_types', 'date', 'huge', 'junk', 'xss', 'quick', 'bad_numbers', 'bad_urls', 'traversal', 'rce', 'sqli', 'xml' ] self.content_types = { 'atom_xml': 'application/atom+xml', 'app_xml': 'application/xml', 'txt_xml': 'text/xml', 'app_soap_xml': 'application/soap+xml', 'app_rdf_xml': 'application/rdf+xml', 'app_rss_xml': 'application/rss+xml', 'app_js': 'application/javascript', 'app_ecma': 'application/ecmascript', 'app_x_js': 'application/x-javascript', 'txt_js': 'text/javascript', 'app_pkcs12': 'application/x-pkcs12', 'app_form': 'application/x-www-form-urlencoded', 'multipart_enc': 'multipart/encrypted', 'multipart_form': 'multipart/form-data', 'msg_http': 'message/http', 'msg_partial': 'message/partial', 'junk': 'junk', } self.date = { 'date_w_null': '2018-02-28T19:14:44.180394' + chr(0x00), 'date_w_unicode': '2018-02-28T19:14:44.180394' + unichr(0xff), 'date_w_format': '2018-02-28T19:%f14:44.180394', 'huge': '2018-02-28T12:12:12.' + ('4' * 100000), } self.huge = { '10^3': 'a' * 10 ** 3, '10^4': 'a' * 10 ** 4, '10^5': 'a' * 10 ** 5, '10^6': 'a' * 10 ** 6, '10^7': 'a' * 10 ** 7 } self.xss = { 'double_bracket': '<', 'tag_close': '\'">', 'img_js_link': '', 'img_js_link_w_0x0D': '', 'img_js_link_overencode': "", 'iframe_js_link': '', 'js_context': '\\\'";alert(1);//' } self.sqli = { 'hex_select': '\\x27\\x4F\\x52 SELECT *', 'hex_select_2': '\\x27\\x6F\\x72 SELECT *', 'hex_select_raw': '\x27\x4F\x52 SELECT *', 'hex_select_raw': '\x27\x6F\x72 SELECT *', 'hex_union': '\\x27UNION SELECT', 'hex_union_raw': '\x27UNION SELECT', 'or_select': '\'"or select *', 'or_x_is_x': '\' or \'x\'=\'x', '0_or_1_is_1': '0 or 1=1', '0_or_1_is_1_dashed': '0 or 1=1--', 'a_or_x_is_x_dquote': 'a" or "x"="x', 'a_or_x_is_x_squote': 'a\' or \'x\'=\'x', 'a_or_x_is_x_paren_dqoute': 'a") or ("x"="x', 'a_or_x_is_x_paren_sqoute': 'a\') or (\'x\'=\'x', 'a_or_x_is_x_full_statement': '\'a\' or \'x\'=\'x\';', 'xml': '' '' } self.xml = { 'xml_xxe_etc_passwd': '' ']>&xxe;' } self.junk = { 'nullbyte': unichr(0x00), 'higher_ascii': unichr(0x80) + unichr(0xfe), 'higher_unicode': unichr(0x1111) + unichr(0xffff), 'unicode_single_quote': unichr(0x2018), 'unicode_double_quote': unichr(0x201c), 'null_unencoded': '\\00', } self.bad_numbers = { 'negative_zero': '-0', 'negative_hex': '-0xff', 'overflow': 999999999999999, 'negative_overflow': -999999999999999, 'negative_float_overflow': -0.999999999999999, 'hex_overflow': '0xffffffff', 'extreme_overflow': 9 ** 100, 'nullbyte': chr(0x00) } self.rce = { 'semicolon_id': ';id', 'or_id': '||id', 'pipe_id': '|id', 'and_id': '&&id', 'nullbyte_id': unichr(0x00) + 'id', 'urlencoded_nullbyte_id': '%00id', 'urlencoded_newline_id': '%0aid', 'backticks_id': '`id`', 'close_parens_id': ');id' } self.bad_urls = { 'javascript': 'javascript:alert(1);', 'data_img_b64': 'data:image/png;base64,junkjunk', 'data_xml_b64': 'data:applicaton/xml;charset=utf-8,' + urllib.quote_plus(''), 'file_etc_passwd': 'file:///etc/passwd', 'relative_etc_passwd': '///etc/passwd', 'back_slashes': '\etc\passwd', } self.traversal = { 'etc_passwd_generic': '../../../../../../../../../../../../etc/passwd', 'etc_passwd_long_w_null_html': '../../../../../../../../../../../../etc/passwd%00.html', 'etc_passwd_urlencoded': '..%5c..%5c..%5c..%5c..%5c..%5c..%5c..%5cetc/passwd', 'etc_passwd_w_null_html': '/etc/passwd%00.html', 'etc_passwd_overencoded_w_null_html': '%2e%2e%2f%2e%2e%2f%2e%2e%2f%2e%2e%2f%2e%2e%2fetc/passwd%00' 'index.html', 'etc_passwd_cwd_long': '/./././././././././././etc/passwd', 'etc_passwd_alternating': '/..\../..\../..\../..\../..\../..\../etc/passwd', 'etc_passwd_back_slashes_w_null': '\..\..\..\..\..\..\..\..\..\..\etc\passwd%00', 'etc_passwd_w_nulls': '%00/etc/passwd%00', 'etc_passwd_urlencoded_w_null': '/..%c0%af../..%c0%af../..%c0%af../..%c0%af../..%c0%af../' '..%c0%af../etc/passwd%00', 'etc_passwd_overencoded_w_null': '/%2e%2e/%2e%2e/%2e%2e/%2e%2e/%2e%2e/%2e%2e/%2e%2e/%2e%2e/' '%2e%2e/%2e%2e/etc/passwd%00', 'etc_passwd_overencoded_w': '%c0%2e%c0%2e%c0%5c%c0%2e%c0%2e%c0%5c%c0%2e%c0%2e%c0%5c%c0' '%2e%c0%2e%c0%5cetc/passwd', 'etc_passwd_overencoded_backslashes': '%25c0%25ae%25c0%25ae\%25c0%25ae%25c0%25ae\%25c0%25ae%25c0' '%25ae\%25c0%25ae%25c0%25ae\%25c0%25ae%25c0%25ae\etc/passwd', 'etc_passwd_overencoded_unicode': '%uff0e%uff0e%u2216%uff0e%uff0e%u2216%uff0e%uff0e%u2216' '%uff0e%uff0e%u2216etc/passwd', 'etc_passwd_urlencoded_w_null_long': '%25%5c..%25%5c..%25%5c..%25%5c..%25%5c..%25%5c..%25%5c..' '%25%5c..%25%5c..%25%5c..%25%5c..%25%5c..%25%5c..%25%5c..' 'etc%25%5cpasswd%00', 'etc_passwd_double_encoded': '%%32%65%%32%65/%%32%65%%32%65/%%32%65%%32%65/%%32%65%%32%65/' '%%32%65%%32%65/etc/passwd', 'etc_passwd_mix_back_slashes': '.\\..\\.\\..\\.\\..\\.\\..\\.\\..\\.\\..\\.\\..\\.\\..\\' 'etc/passwd', 'etc_passwd_triple_slash': '..///..///..///..///..///..///..///..///etc/passwd', 'etc_passwd_long_leading_dots': '.' * 72 + '/../../../../../../etc/passwd' } def get_strings(self, fuzz_string_type=None, encoding=None): """Get a set of fuzz strings based on fuzz_string_type and encoding Valid types defined in self.types """ fuzz_strings = [] if fuzz_string_type not in self.types or fuzz_string_type is None: fuzz_string_type = self.default_fuzz_type # Generate fuzz strings on the fly elif fuzz_string_type == "ascii": for i in xrange(0, 256): fuzz_strings.append(chr(i)) elif fuzz_string_type == "unicode": for i in xrange(0, 0x1000): fuzz_strings.append(unichr(i)) for i in xrange(0xf800, 0x10000): # Random fuzz_strings.append(unichr(i)) elif fuzz_string_type == "content_types": for name in self.content_types: fuzz_strings.append(self.content_types[name]) elif fuzz_string_type == "xss": for name in self.xss: fuzz_strings.append(self.xss[name]) elif fuzz_string_type == "json_recursion": obj = {} string = 'obj["hax"]' for i in xrange(850): exec(string + ' = {}') string += '["hax"]' fuzz_strings.append(json.dumps(obj)) # Get pre-generated fuzz strings elif fuzz_string_type in self.named_types: temp = self.__dict__[fuzz_string_type] for name in temp: fuzz_strings.append(temp[name]) return fuzz_strings def get_dataset(self, fuzz_string_type): """Get the fuzz string dataset for use in parameterized tests""" strings = self.get_strings(fuzz_string_type) result = {} for string in strings: name = self.get_fuzz_string_name(fuzz_string_type, string) result[name] = [string] return result def get_datasets(self, fuzz_string_types): """Get multiple datasets for use in parameterized tests""" result = {} for fuzz_type in fuzz_string_types: strings = self.get_strings(fuzz_type) for string in strings: name = '{0}_{1}'.format( fuzz_type, self.get_fuzz_string_name(fuzz_type, string) ) result[name] = {'fuzz_type': fuzz_type, 'payload': string} return result def get_fuzz_string_name(self, fuzz_string_type, fuzz_string, num=False): """Get the name of a fuzz string (pre-defined above or generated)""" result = None if fuzz_string_type in self.named_types: for name, string in self.__dict__[fuzz_string_type].iteritems(): if string == fuzz_string: result = name break else: # Get first 20 characters, trim trailing spaces, convert # non-alphanumeric characters to underscores fuzz_string = re.sub( "[^a-z0-9A-Z]*", "_", fuzz_string[:20].strip() ) result = "{0}_{1}".format(fuzz_string_type, fuzz_string) if num is not False and isinstance(num, int): result = "{0}_{1}".format(result, num) return result def verify_response(self, resp, fuzz_type='generic'): """Look for signs of vulnerability in fuzz test response based on type - Assertion fail if 5XX HTTP status code - Assertion fail if indication of vulnerability found in respnse body """ fuzz_type = fuzz_type.lower() text = resp.text.lower() assert(resp.status_code not in range(500, 600)) # RCE should return results of `id` command, containing "uid=" if fuzz_type == 'rce': assert('uid=' not in text) # Traversal should return /etc/passwd, containing "root:*" elif fuzz_type == 'traversal': assert('root:' not in text) # SQL injection should return 'SQL' or 'syntax' in body elif fuzz_type == 'sqli': assert('sql' not in text) assert('syntax' not in text) # Crude XSS filter: find alert(1) in text body elif fuzz_type == 'xss': assert('alert(1)' not in text) # Just run generic checks (check for 500 for now) elif fuzz_type == 'generic': pass

subject: Special Handling for Functional Tests that don't support concurrency
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-08-25 13:46:08.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/barbican/commit/e8c3aa5d74e10c6cb79a10c5c335a9009ca8ba37', 'message': 'Skip Functional Tests that don't support concurrency when using concurrency

The project quotas paging test cases do not support concurrency.
Since they all use the same database, checks that verify a specific
number of things are in that database might fail if other tests
are concurrently adding/deleting things from that database.

This commit marks those tests with the "no_concurrency" attribute, and
then instructs tox to skip those tests when running functional tests
with concurrency requested.

Change-Id: I56740a4993b5b9c7976b3c52a701605cd5815a5b
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2015-08-25 14:39:15.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/barbican/commit/3dd94ac97f3bd8acb8e496a5bcbba5e42c84a61a', 'message': 'Skip Functional Tests that don't support concurrency when using concurrency

The project quotas paging test cases do not support concurrency.
Since they all use the same database, checks that verify a specific

commit_message:
Special Handling for Functional Tests that don't support concurrency

The project quotas paging test cases do not support concurrency.
Since they all use the same database, checks that verify a specific
number of things are in that database might fail if other tests
are concurrently adding/deleting things from that database.

This commit marks those tests with the "no_concurrency" attribute, and
then instructs tox to run those tests separately when running functional
tests.  Marked tests will be run first without the --processes=-1 flag.
Unmarked tests will be run next with the --processes=-1, to enable
parallel test runs.

Change-Id: I56740a4993b5b9c7976b3c52a701605cd5815a5b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/barbican refs/changes/15/216715/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: commands = nosetests -v --processes=-1 -a '!no_concurrency' --process-timeout=600 {toxinidir}/functionaltests {posargs}

commit_message:
Wrote fuzz tests for ACLs

These tests will attempt CRUD operations on ACLs, replacing parameters in the
request with common attack strings used in penetration testing. We check the
requests for server side error messages and for the presence of attack strings
in the response.

Currently, most API methods will be tested for the following issues:

- Remote code execution (RCE)
- SQL injection (SQLi)
- DoS/500 errors via various junk payloads (conversion errors, etc.)

Change-Id: I00321d5c58d097e96ad1884da29768b66e898132
Related-Bug: #1481021

commit_message:
Use oslo.versionedobjects to help with upgrades

Specification blueprint versioned-objects

Change-Id: I1a7d3a2ca90ed77d2195bc641dd0142364ae66dc
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/barbican-specs refs/changes/18/174318/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ============================================================== Use oslo.versionedobjects to help with dealing with upgrades. ============================================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/barbican/+spec/versioned-objects oslo.versionedobjects library deals with DB schema being at different versions than the code expects, allowing services to be operated safely during upgrades. Problem Description =================== We are looking to improve the way we deal with versioning (of all sorts db/rpc/rest/plugins). Nova has come up with the idea of versioned objects, that Ironic, Swift and other projects have also now used. The code has now been separated into an oslo library: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/127532/ which has already been used in Heat. https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/kilo-crossproject-upgrades-and-versioning Versionedobjects will help us deal with DB schema being at a different version than the code expects. This will allow Barbican to be operated safely during upgrades. Looking forward as we pass more and more data over RPC we can make use of versionedobjects to ensure upgrades happen without spreading the version dependant code across the code base. Proposed Change =============== Create a directory barbican/objects/ that will contain wrapper objects that are a layer above the db objects. This allows the remainder of Barbican to not have to worry about dealing with older DB objects. Once the objects are in place the rest of the code will be changed to use versionedobjects instead of the db_api directly. This can be done object-by-object to avoid overly large changes. Alternatives ------------ Data Model Impact ----------------- None. The objects being introduced are not stored in the database. Instead, these objects are a replacement for sqlalchemy objects that is being used to represent stack, resource, etc throughout Barbican internals. REST API Impact --------------- None. Security Impact --------------- None. Notifications & Audit Impact ---------------------------- None. Other End User Impact --------------------- None. Performance Impact ------------------ Minimal. Other Deployer Impact --------------------- This enables the possibility of rolling upgrades. Developer Impact ---------------- It will take some time to convert Barbican internals over to the object model, so the existing convention of direct database calls should be accepted until all object models are in place. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: Grzegorz Grasza <grzegorz.grasza@intel.com> <others are welcome to help out> Work Items ---------- * Implement the objects for each DB object type we have. * Update code that uses the DB to use versioned-objects instead. * Write some developer docs on how to deal with older schema. Dependencies ============ * oslo.versionedobjects Testing ======= Testing of upgrades can be done with grenade, but this is out of scope of this specification. Documentation Impact ==================== References ========== * https://blueprints.launchpad.net/heat/+spec/versioned-objects

commit_message:
Introduce the concept of an Active SecretStore

Introduce the concept of Active and Inactive SecretStore plugins. Active
SecretStore will be limited to one and only one, but you may have zero
or more inactive SecretStores.

Change-Id: I8a9601214c8b1c422dc7333a38868efd26789b13
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/barbican-specs refs/changes/79/135779/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ============================================== Introduce the concept of an Active SecretStore ============================================== Launchpad blueprint: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/barbican/+spec/active-secret-store As discussed during the `Kilo Design Summit`_ we would like to reduce the complexity of the Barbican plugin system by limiting the amount of SecretStore plugins to just one Active plugin. .. _`Kilo Design Summit` https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/barbican-kilo-plugin-lifecycle Problem Description =================== Currently, Barbican allows SecretStore plugins to be configured in an unbounded list. The list is iterated every time to find the first plugin that can store or generate the desired key. This adds a lot of complexity to Barbican without adding much value, since it's not possible to know until runtime where exaclty the encrypted data will be stored. Proposed Change =============== This blueprint proposes adding the concept of Active and Inactive plugins. There should be one and only one Active plugin at any given time. The :class:`SecretStorePluginManager` would be changed such that storing or generating secrets would always be done with the Active plugin. In order to support migrating to a new Active plugin, this blueprint proposes allowing the configuration of zero or more Inactive plugins. These plugins would effectively be working in a read-only mode. When retrieving a secret, Barbican would first check the Active SecretStore. If the secret is not available there, Barbican would iterate through the Inactive plugins until the secret is found and returned. This will allow an operator to continue to serve all secrets while migrating to the new secret store out-of-band. Alternatives ------------ The alternative would be to continue to allow storage/generation of secrets in one of many configured SecretStore plugins. Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- None Security impact --------------- This change should allow to determine exactly where a secret will be stored since it would no longer be determined at runtime. This may help with some auditing requirements. Notifications & Audit Impact ---------------------------- Auditing for secret storage should be easier, since we know that the Active plugin will always be used. Other end user impact --------------------- This change should not impact the client. Performance Impact ------------------ We may see an improvement in storage/generation since we would no longer need to loop through every avaiable plugin every time a request is processesed. Other deployer impact --------------------- Configuration will change so that [secretstore] section has a place to specify the active plugin, as well as specifying a list of Inactive plugins. Developer impact ---------------- None. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: Douglas Mendizbal (redrobot) Work Items ---------- * Refactor SecretStorePluginManger to add methods for retrieving the Active plugin * Refactor barbican.plugin.resources.py so that store_secret and generate_secret always use the Active plugin * Refactor barbican.plugin.resources.py so that get_secret looks in both Active and Inactive plugins Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= Functional testing should be added to ensure secret storage and retrieval is working correctly when you have both Active and Inactive plugins. Documentation Impact ==================== Docs referencing the plugin system will have to be updated. References ========== https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/barbican-kilo-plugin-lifecycle https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/barbican-kilo-design-sessions

commit_message:
Add more info on setting up Dockerized Keystone

This CR adds more detail on configuring Barbican to work with the
'simple dockerized keystone' local development mode.

Change-Id: I7c49e4b8941602cb8cf57f26db733a45a1c9ad1a
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/barbican refs/changes/14/169114/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: When using the `Simple Dockerized Keystone`_ option, you should modify your local Barbican repository's ``./etc/barbican/barbican-functional.conf`` file as follows, noting that the ``DOCKER_KEYSTONE_HOST`` could be ``localhost`` for Linux environments, or else an IP such as ``192.168.59.103`` for Mac OSX .. code-block:: ini [DEFAULT] [identity] # Replace these with values that represent your identity configuration uri=http://{DOCKER_KEYSTONE_HOST}:5000/v3 version=v3 username=admin project_name=admin password=password domain_name=Default [keymanager] # use this to run the functional tests against a # different barbican server than the one that is # specified in the service catalog. To use what is # in the service catalog, just comment this out # or leave it blank. override_url=http://localhost:9311 override_url_version=v1 To run an individual Python module's functional tests on your local machine you can use a command such as in this example, which executes all the functional tests in the test_orders.py module .. code-block:: bash # Only execute functional tests in the test_orders.py module nosetests -v --processes=-1 --process-timeout=240 ./functionaltests/api/v1/functional/test_orders.py .. _Simple Dockerized Keystone: https://registry.hub.docker.com/u/ jmvrbanac/simple-keystone/

commit_message:
Barbican objects base

This patch is to insert the objects code base, It based on
oslo_versionedobjects.  This is done to make progress on
changing barbican internals to use VersionObjects.

Inserted objects code base into barbican and modified barbican
services to use object-aware serializer.

Change-Id: Ieca60e2303f3ff679f2a035b0e0a373e64404d49
Implements: blueprint barbican-objects
Author: Daniel Tadrzak <daniel.tadrzak@intel.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/barbican refs/changes/41/202141/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Copyright 2015 Intel Corporation # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. """Barbican common internal object model""" import contextlib import datetime import functools import traceback from oslo_log import log as logging from oslo_versionedobjects import base from oslo_versionedobjects import fields import six from barbican.common import exception from barbican import objects LOG = logging.getLogger('object') remotable = base.remotable remotable_classmethod = base.remotable_classmethod obj_make_list = base.obj_make_list class BarbicanObjectRegistry(base.VersionedObjectRegistry): def registration_hook(self, cls, index): setattr(objects, cls.obj_name(), cls) @BarbicanObjectRegistry.register class BarbicanObject(base.VersionedObject): # NOTE(DTadrzak): OBJ_PROJECT_NAMESPACE needs to be set so that nova, # Barbican, and other objects can exist on the same bus and be # distinguished from one another. OBJ_PROJECT_NAMESPACE = 'barbican' def barbican_obj_get_changes(self): """Returns a dict of changed fields with tz unaware datetimes. Any timezone aware datetime field will be converted to UTC timezone and returned as timezone unaware datetime. This will allow us to pass these fields directly to a db update method as they can't have timezone information. """ # Get dirtied/changed fields changes = self.obj_get_changes() # Look for datetime objects that contain timezone information for k, v in changes.items(): if isinstance(v, datetime.datetime) and v.tzinfo: # Remove timezone information and adjust the time according to # the timezone information's offset. changes[k] = v.replace(tzinfo=None) - v.utcoffset() # Return modified dict return changes class BarbicanObjectDictCompat(base.VersionedObjectDictCompat): """Mix-in to provide dictionary key access compat. If an object needs to support attribute access using dictionary items instead of object attributes, inherit from this class. This should only be used as a temporary measure until all callers are converted to use modern attribute access. NOTE(DTadrzak) This class will eventually be deleted. """ def get(self, key, value=base._NotSpecifiedSentinel): """For backwards-compatibility with dict-based objects. NOTE(DTadrzak): May be removed in the future. """ if key not in self.obj_fields: # NOTE(jdg): There are a number of places where we rely on the # old dictionary version and do a get(xxx, None). # The following preserves that compatibility but in # the future we'll remove this shim altogether so don't # rely on it. LOG.debug('Barbican object %(object_name)s has no ' 'attribute named: %(attribute_name)s', {'object_name': self.__class__.__name__, 'attribute_name': key}) return None if (value != base._NotSpecifiedSentinel and not self.obj_attr_is_set(key)): return value else: return getattr(self, key) class BarbicanPersistentObject(object): """Mixin class for Persistent objects. This adds the fields that we use in common for all persistent objects. """ fields = { 'created_at': fields.DateTimeField(nullable=True), 'updated_at': fields.DateTimeField(nullable=True), 'deleted_at': fields.DateTimeField(nullable=True), 'deleted': fields.BooleanField(default=False), } @contextlib.contextmanager def obj_as_admin(self): """Context manager to make an object call as an admin. This temporarily modifies the context embedded in an object to be elevated() and restores it after the call completes. Example usage: with obj.obj_as_admin(): obj.save() """ if self._context is None: raise exception.OrphanedObjectError(method='obj_as_admin', objtype=self.obj_name()) original_context = self._context self._context = self._context.elevated() try: yield finally: self._context = original_context class BarbicanObjectSerializer(base.VersionedObjectSerializer): OBJ_BASE_CLASS = BarbicanObject def serialize_args(fn): """Decorator that will do the arguments serialization before remoting.""" def wrapper(obj, *args, **kwargs): for kw in kwargs: value_arg = kwargs.get(kw) if kw == 'exc_val' and value_arg: kwargs[kw] = str(value_arg) elif kw == 'exc_tb' and ( not isinstance(value_arg, six.string_types) and value_arg): kwargs[kw] = ''.join(traceback.format_tb(value_arg)) elif isinstance(value_arg, datetime.datetime): kwargs[kw] = value_arg.isoformat() if hasattr(fn, '__call__'): return fn(obj, *args, **kwargs) # NOTE(danms): We wrap a descriptor, so use that protocol return fn.__get__(None, obj)(*args, **kwargs) # NOTE(danms): Make this discoverable wrapper.remotable = getattr(fn, 'remotable', False) wrapper.original_fn = fn return (functools.wraps(fn)(wrapper) if hasattr(fn, '__call__') else classmethod(wrapper))

commit_message:
Added spec for copy constructor for secrets and containers

Change-Id: Ie4b68e6921188a3a6d42f1cfda31cf23fe81b26c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/barbican-specs refs/changes/23/127823/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ============================================== Add API option to copy secrets and containers ============================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/barbican/+spec/barbican-add-copy-constructor Problem Description =================== In cinder, it is sometimes necessary to clone a barbican secret, for example, when storing the encryption key for a cloned disk. Currently, this is done by retrieving and re-storing the secret. This would be better done in the barbican server directly, so that secrets need not be manipulated outside the barbican server. In this spec, we propose adding options to the API to allow the cloning of secrets and containers on the server. Proposed Change =============== For secrets, an optional parameter "copy_id" will be added to the POST /secrets and PUT /secret/foo requests. If that parameter is present, then all other parameters in the request will be ignored. "copy_id" should contain the UUID of a secret to be cloned. If the secret des not exist, then a 400 error (Bad Request) will be thrown. Otherwise, a new secret will be created with the metadata of the old secret, and the secret_data will be cloned. As with the normal PUT/POST operation, we will return the UUID of the new secret. Internally, this will be accomplished by calling a new method copy_secret() in the secret_store interface. Ideally, plugins would implement copy_secret() via operations that would not require secrets to actually be retrieved from the plugin. However, so that plugins need not immediately implement the new method, a default method will be provided in the secret_store() interface. For containers, an option parameter "copy_id" will be added to POST and PUT operations. The operation is similar to the above. The metadata will be cloned, and call secrets will be cloned using copy_secret(). Alternatives ------------ Leave the code-base as it is. Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- One new parameter "copy_id" will be added to POST and PUT operations for secrets and containers. Security impact --------------- Security is improved because secrets are not needlessly exposed. Notifications & Audit Impact ---------------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- python-barbicanclient will need to be changed to take advantage of this new API call. Nova/Cinder code may similar be affected. Performance Impact ------------------ Should be more efficient because fewer API interactions are required. Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- None. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) Primary assignee: alee akoneru Adam Harwell (client) Work Items ---------- * Implement in server (pretty easy) * Modify barbican client/ nova and cinder code Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= The current unit tests will also be modified to have this change reflected upon them. Documentation Impact ==================== New API call should be documented. References ========== None

subject: Save order information on created secrets/containers
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-01-14 18:29:31.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/barbican-specs/commit/baa81c3a4c0c0955ebe6b504ee611d733ff61349', 'message': "Save order information on created secrets/containers

Currently there is no information stored on created secrets/containers
as to the order that was used to create them. It would be useful for
information such as the order's metadata to be available to clients
when created secrets or containers are retrieved. Also, there are some
SSL-related workflows involving existing certificate containers that
require information from the original order and order-plugin metadata.
For example, certificate reissue or revocation workflows require
information found only in the original order and plugin metadata such

the certificate (stored in order plugin metadata), or original contact
information (stored in order metadata). This blueprint proposes means

commit_message:
Save order information on created secrets/containers

Currently there is no information stored on created secrets/containers
as to the order that was used to create them. It would be useful for
information such as the order's metadata to be available to clients
when created secrets or containers are retrieved. Also, there are some
SSL-related workflows involving existing certificate containers that
require information from the original order and order-plugin metadata.
For example, certificate reissue or revocation workflows require
information found only in the original order and plugin metadata such
as the original certificate authority (CA) order ID used to generate
the certificate (stored in order plugin metadata), or original contact
information (stored in order metadata). This blueprint proposes means
to store the information for later access.

APIImpact: Adds an 'order_ref' element to the orders resource response
DocImpact: Update orders resource doc to include 'order_ref'
SecurityImpact: Orders entities could be long-lived now
Implements: blueprint save-order-info-on-created-secrets
Change-Id: I6022ef7d5a9cec34abed05cceb95e226b1133e56
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/barbican-specs refs/changes/67/147267/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ==================================================== Save order information on created secrets/containers ==================================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/barbican/+spec/save-order-info-on-created-secrets Currently there is no information stored on created secrets/containers as to the order that was used to create them. It would be useful for information such as the order's metadata to be available to clients when created secrets or containers are retrieved. Also, there are some SSL-related workflows involving existing certificate containers that require information from the original order and order-plugin metadata. For example, certificate reissue or revocation workflows require information found only in the original order and plugin metadata such as the original certificate authority (CA) order ID used to generate the certificate (stored in order plugin metadata), or original contact information (stored in order metadata). This blueprint proposes means to store the information for later access. Problem Description =================== At least three use cases need access to the original order information used to generate Barbican containers: user interfaces and clients that wish to retrieve detailed information about secrets and containers, certificate reissues and certificate revocations. When metadata for secrets and orders are retrieved, it would be useful for clients to also see the original order metadata used to create them. Some information, such as contact information for SSL certificates, is not available from the certificate (in the form of a Barbican container) data alone. In the reissue use case, a previously-generated certificate container could have been compromised requiring that a new certificate be generated and stored in a new Barbican container. The certificate revocation use case involves letting the CA know that an existing container's certificate needs to be revoked. Eventually we will add new Barbican API calls (outside of this blueprint) for these use cases that will need to refer to the original certificate container via its UUID. Not all of the information needed for these operations is available from the container's certificate alone however. For example, the original CA order ID (stored in the order's plugin metadata) is required for the Symantec CA at least. Also, only information needed to validate a certificate the first time is added to the produced certificate. So for example 'company name' will not show up in the certificate if it was not needed to validate the certificate. This information might be needed for the follow on operations, or as a minimum would be useful for clients to be able to view their certificate information after they are created. Proposed Change =============== Two approaches may be taken to save original order information with the secrets/containers created from them: add an order foreign key (FK) to the to the secret and container entities, or copy the order metadata and plugin metadata to the secret and container entities. This blueprint suggests adding a FK to the secret and container entities, to take advantage of the orders' data model relationships and entities already established to store this information. One concern with this approach however is that order entities are no longer just workflow 'jobs' that only need to exist long enough for an asynchronous operation to complete, and could then be hard removed later. Orders would instead need to be persisted as long as their associated secrets and containers exist. Hard removal of orders would still be possible if the secrets or containers associated to them are removed. This order metadata would then be returned as part of the secret and container metadata from GET requests. The order's plugin metadata would *not* be returned to the client as this is internal to Barbican core's operation. Alternatives ------------ As mentioned above, an alternative approach is to copy the order and plugin metadata to the new secrets and containers created from those orders. This would require adding identical attributes and entities to secrets and containers as on the order entity now, which seems wasteful. If reviewers are fine with keeping order records around as long as associated secrets or containers exist, then it seems that this alternative is not the best choice. Data model impact ----------------- An FK to the orders entity would be added to both secrets and containers. This would need to be a nullable field as only order-created secrets and containers would have an associated order record. REST API impact --------------- This blueprint proposes returning available order metadata (not the plugin metadata) along with the secret/container metadata on GET requests. If the order FK was not populated, then the existing response data would be returned. Security impact --------------- There is no security impact as the same metadata provided when GET-ting an order would be returned when GET-tting a secret or container, and the same role policy is enforced for orders GETs as for secrets and container GETs. This change does mean that order records could be long-lived within Barbican elevating the chance of resource exhaustion attacks. Quota management (per a different blueprint) should mitigate this attack. Notifications & Audit Impact ---------------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- The python-barbicanclient should be updated to output the additional order metadata for retrieved order-generated secrets and containers. Performance Impact ------------------ There will be an additional processing load when retrieving secrets and containers that have associated orders, due to additional joins to the order and metadata records. The response messages of order-generated secrets and containers will likewise be larger by the size of the order metadata, consuming more network bandwidth. Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: TBD Other contributors: john-wood-w Work Items ---------- 1) Add FK to orders entity, on the secrets and containers entities. 2) Populate this FK when secrets and containers are created via orders. 3) Update the to-dictionary logic of the secrets and containers models, to return order metadata if the order FK is populated. 4) Add unit tests to validate operation. 5) Add functional tests to validate operation. 6) Update API documentation. Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= Data model related unit testing will need to be augmented to verify the optional order FK can be used to retrieve order and order metadata records. Functional tests will need to be augmented to test that secret/containers created via orders indeed have order metadata available during metadata GETs. Documentation Impact ==================== Update API documentation on secret and container GETs to indicate that additional order metadata may be returned if available. References ========== None
